editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ACTED BY The QVEENES Maieſties SERVANTS.

l.hi: Fabula, quae poſci vult, & ſpectata reponi.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by George Purſlowe for Richard Woodroffe, and are to be ſold at his Shop neere the great North-dore of Paules, at the ſigne of the guilded Key. 1616.

div.head: Act. Prim.
div.l: A Cuckold? why now it is a common name,
As the ſhee-Goſsip • are that giue it vs.
Why doth it not deriue, and ſpread it ſelfe.
To all the generations we produce?
Why ſhould not euery child of mine be call'd
Cuckold, as well as Ʋaster, Woman, woman
Thou ſad vndoer of the faireſt building,
That euer earth bragg'd to be pauement to.
Man, Man; the pride of heauens creation,
Abſtract of Nature, that in his ſmall volume
Containes the whole worlds Text, and heauens impreſsion:
His Makers Image, Angels mate, Earths great wonder,
Made to guide all, by woman is brought vnder.
That harmonie, faire Nature made to ſtand,
Is forced out of tune by womans hand.
A woman hath deform'd me. See, I looke
Like any beaſt has hornes: an Aſſe may boaſt
Himſelfe a horne-leſſe Gentleman before me.
Yet let not clouds of paſsion choke my reaſon.
Why? what's a Cuckold? let's ſee: define him:
div.p:
It is a man, whoſe wife playes the whore. Zilid, what's that to him? It is all one, as if a proper Gentleman ſhould ride on a halting Iade; or a good Muſician play on a broken fiddle. Oh but t'will be ſayd: Woman could not be ſo light a ſhippe, if her huſband could well ballaſt her. It is his inſufficiencie. A poxe it is.
Had ſhe Hercules to her husband, ſhee would enter the liſtes with ſome crinkle-hamm'd tilting Courtier. Well then,
div.l: I ſee no reaſon, that a womans euill,
Should thus transforme man to a horned deuill,
No: 'twas Acteons luſts, and not his wife,
That ſo beſtagg'd him. Hence ſprouts al my ſhame.
Fuller of truth then age, thi • rule hath beene:
" Nothing deformes a man, but his owne ſinne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, my mother prayes—

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: No more of her. Her prayers.
Are putrid ſacrifices: like foule ayres,
Too thicke to mount vp to yon glorious feeling.
" When blacke hands are rear'd vp, heauen has no feeling.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: She is your wife, my mother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you wrong her, ô my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Oh tis a braue Puritan-world, when boyes talke of conſcience! Conſcience muſt lye at the ſtake, when they play but at blow-point. Sirrah, as you loue your Conſcience, hate a wife. Zlid, if I thought thou wouldſt marry, I would vnbleſſe thee, as I haue diſinherited thee already: Get baſtards, as I would ha' got thee. A woman may ſerue to lye withal: none good enough to marry.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Oh were you not my father, I would let
This paſsion out of your impoſtum'd heart—
Why ſhould not I forget, that your bloud moues
In any veines of mine; when you forgoe
The reaſon of a father, husband, man?
And ſticke degeneration on your name?
If I ſayle ill, know your example ſteer'd
My voyage and my veſſell. Fathers are more
Then priuate men: their liues are the ſet copies.
Their children write by; and ſhould there giue
Their imitation patternes how to liue.
Hell's a ſad place, they ſay:—Oh, Ile dare neuer
To follow my owne father leading thither.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Sirra, call your mother. This boy's a Puritan.
I that had nere lou'd my ſelfe to be thought good,
Am highly pleaſd to ſee it in my blood.
From whom deriues this ſprigge ſuch fruitfull iuyce;
The father being bad, the mother worſe.
Sure, he did ſucke this goodneſſe from his Nurſe.
Poore boy, my riot has vndone thee: poore
Thou'rt made by me, I by a wife turnd whore.
My ſtate is morgag'd to the vſurous hand
Of Gripe: my goods are waſted: all my hopes life
Breathes thus: hauing ſold all, Ile ſell my wife.
sp.p: Y' are welcome, Looſeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Looſeneſſe Sir? Oh hell!
She is my mother; pray you, vſe her well.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I cannot Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good ſonne, a way.
A father giues command.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I muſt obay.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: Make much of you? I will, I will. Neuer man made more of his wife, when he ſold her to her ſmocke. Ile ſell thy fleſh too Gypſey.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Deare husband, I am yet cleare; Oh do not you
Force me to ſinne, Ile be for ouer true.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: True? true to the brothell, to the ſpittle, to the graue.
Thou art deaths agent: a whore is one of his Beadles.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Heauen pardon your blacke ſlanders.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: Come, I'm poore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Who made you?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Thou, my content, turn'd whore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile worke, or beg for you.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No, thou haſt wrought
Too much already. Here, here's thy worke.
Wilt thou doe one thing?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Then ſweare.
And keepe thy oath. Ile trauell to the warres,
And turne thee vp, as ſome Captaines wont; and trie,
If thou canſt liue by thy old trade, or die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you forſake me then?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Yes, and am iuſt.
Since thou forſook'ſt me, and thine innocence,
Be thy reward proportion'd I muſt hence.
Whiles thou waſt good, to thee I had free deſire.
Now thou art prou'd a whore receaue thy hire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Take place, thou tyrant will. Thicke woes here houer.
My ſtate is lower then fate can recouer.
My obedience waits your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Hoh, within there.
Aunt Marre-maid I haue brought you the girle
I promiſd. Is the mony ready?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: By that little honeſty I haue to ſweare by; a handſome wench. I muſt pay fiftie pound for her: but if ſhee were as yong, as faire, I would get fiue hundred pound by her within this moneth.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Aunt, pray' vſe her well: ſhe's my owne ſiſter.

Be petulāt you whore, ſprightly frollick—as a Dutch Tanikin.—or—This woman is a Bawd, a very Bawd; you like her the better for that. Come, skippe about, quicke ſiluer: Dance like a Curteſan, or Ile fiddle ye. You ha' more trickes in priuate, then a Fencer can teach a Lord, or the diuell a Fencer. Life, doe you pule? I muſt haue fiftie pound for you: Doe y' heare? Let your heeles caper, and your tongue grow wanton, or by theſe horns Ile gore you—Aunt, ſhee's ſomewhat ſicke of that rare diſeaſe, cald Modeſty. But in priuate ſhe's more inſatiate then a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: How old are you, faire ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Not ſixteene.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: About ſome ſixe and fortie.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Oh you Witch—Aunt, ſhe lies eight and twentie, at leaſt
sp.l: Harke ye ſiſter,—
Pleaſe this old Hagge, make her beleeue y' are right,
And anſwerable to her Stygian ſpels:
Or I will beare thee to an Armie, and there
Ha'thy ſod fleſh ſold, lent; and preſtituted,
And my ſelfe Cuckolded fortie times a day.
Leaue this forc'd ſo berneſſe—Aunt, will you heare her ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can skippe lighter then the wanton Doe,
And ierke it through the Dale,
I cannot hold, neither my tongue, nor heeles,
(Nor nailes from ſcratching out a Leachers eyes)
Sure, I am compoſd moſt of the nimbler elements:
But little water in me, farre leſſe earth, ſome aire,
To keepe me humid, mutable, and tender,
And apt for conuolution: but their mixture
Is ſcarce diſcernible, th' are ſo diſpers'd.
For my predominant qualitie is all fire,
Pure, radiant, ſubtle fire.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: I haue oft ſeene a couple of light heeles
Carry a ſober head: a womans tongue
Reade lectures of ciuilitie; her face
A printed booke, each dimple a ſweet line,
That doth to good the Readers eye incline,
Neuer till now a body forc'd to doe,
What the poore mind loaths to conſent vnto.
She danceth weeping, laughes and ſighes in paine.
So I haue ſeene (me thinkes) Sun-ſhine in raine.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Enough, I long to imploy her. Couſin, heres the mony. She's mine. Whats your name?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Florence.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Florence. I like the name well.
Its a good lucky name to make a whore on. You'l ſtay with me, Florence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Till you are weary of me. Ile but take leaue of my brother, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: What with me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Am I not worthy of one kiſſe?

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: There—now be gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Be gone? Death could not ſpeake a word more fatall.
Yet one more—ſo now farewell—
Vniuſt—vnkind—my woe-diuining heart.
By this we firſt embrac'd, by this we part.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: I am a villaine, but ſhe makes me weepe.
Why doe I thinke ſhe's falſe? I neuer ſaw't.
Tut, all bels ring that tune. It is too true.
I told her that this fiftie pound ſhould carry me to the warres;
But I haue a battle to fight ere I goe.
Old Gripe that has the morgage of my lands,
Lies ſicke of the Goute, and ſeldome ſtirres abroad.
Some of that race Ile kill, or leaue my owne life
In pawne I would haue done 't. I ha' chalenged
Beniamin Gripe the ſonne, whom the world cals
The Honeſt Lawyer. He comes.
sp.p: Y'are the ſonne of a villaine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: If I were, I could not helpe it.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Thy ſelfe's a villaine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Its a ranke lie.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Lie? Thou exaſperatſt
One mad already, that would haue hazard heauen
To make this earth drunke with thy bloud.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Its deare, ſo bought. Twil not redeeme your ſoule.
Say, with deepe ſluces, all theſe liuely ſprings,
That runne through the ſoft channels of my veines,
Should be exhauſt by thee, or thine by me,
And burning malice ſhould be quencht in bloud:
He that ſpeeds beſt, wins what he ſhould abhorre,
And glories to be curſt a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Let Sophiſters alone with theſe diſtinctions.
Our moderators are our ſwords: the queſtion,
That cals vs forth, as warlike diſputants
Beyond deciſion of the gowne-furr'd peace.
Draw then thy argument, and let's talke indeed.
We cannot reaſon ſoundly, till we bleed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Let's thinke the tearmes, on which we venture bloud.
Th'ffects are waighty, let the cauſe be good.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Thy father hath vndone me, and mine iſſue.
The law affords no ſuccour: what remaines,
But onely to let him bleed through thy vaines?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How haue I wrongd thee?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Aske no more. The State
Of our ſtrife is, thou art his Sonne, I hate.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No helpe? let fury arbitrate the reſt.
This paſſion muſt but center in one breſt.
Yet let's embrace, and pardon; and euen loue
In hate. O ſuffer not the dying blood
To preiudice the ſad ſuruiuours good.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: What vnexpected clangor frights the peace
Of my delighted ſolitary walkes?
What ſonnes of miſchiefe in their fury tread
Theſe vnfrequented pathes?—ſtay—hold.
My ſonnes, heare age but ſpeake; wiſedome is old.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Peace, Dotard.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: On my knees, which doubling age
Hath ſcarce left able to ſupport my corps:
By the remaining teares of fortie yeares
Spent in this penitentiall order: the laſt drops,
The drying hand of age hath left to dew
This witherd garden: I implore—beſeech.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Father, you ſpeake to rocks, or the ſurd waues.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Then on this innocent boſome turn your ſwords,
And eaſe a weake ſoule of her tedious portage,
Some houre before her time. O do not flie me.
Let the few drops of my ſlow-pacing blood,
That ſtands in my cold channels, expiate yours.
Oh let a falling trunke redeeme two plants.
No remedie? let me exclaime for helpe.
sp.p: (The diuell part you:) if I ſhould now ha'paid for my charitie—well: twas this Church-coate that ſau'd me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Oh thou haſt ſlaine me: hold thy conquering hand.
Heauens, you are too iuſt pay-maſters. Thy ſword,
With a fate-ſign'd direction, hath cut ſhort
My hoped fortunes in a longer breath.
But I forgiue thee. Flie—ſtay.
I haue two Orphans in this houre depriu'd
Of a bad Parent. For their mother—nothing.
She has a trade to liue on. O let my dying breath
Beg this one mercie at thy bloud-ſtaind hands:
Releeue them with now thine, once their owne lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgiue my deed, and by that mercie, I
Depend on for my ſinnes; my mercy ſhall
Raiſe vp the children for the fathers fall. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: He's gone. Now vp againe. My wounds
Are ſlight, yet through their windows, heare I breath
Out all my malice. Noble youth, I loue thee.
How little of thy father haſt thou in thee!
Now for ſome ſtrange diſguiſe, till time I find,
To pleaſure him that was to me thus kind.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well, I ſee there's no liuing in London, The foure winds haue conſpirde to blow all the villany of the world thither. When I returnd from my ſhort trauell, I inquir'd, for the knot of my old companions. But like an old Ladie, that has much vſd painting, how ſuddenly are they broken! I heard of three or foure in Bedlam. Fiue or ſixe in Bridewell. Halfe a ſcore ith' Counter. a whole dozen at Tyburne. But Oh, numbers, numbers, vnder the hands of Barber-Surgions. Some turnd Squires to a Brothell. Others walke New-gate lane. Some cheating in Ordinaries. Others prigging in crowds. And the reſt, either ſwomme ouer ſea, or drownd vpon a hill. Well, I do not like theſe proceedings; there bee ſo many rubbes. I could now begge in Dutch, but its no ſpeeding language. Now my villanie failes on the ſea, Ile trie what cheates the land has to worke on. I learn'd ſome ſcuruie medicins of our Surgion of the ſhip: & had no ſooner ſet vp my bils in Bedford here; but a Goutie cure comes halting to mee. Fifty pounds I muſt haue to heale him. Fiue and twentie I haue in pawne: for the reſt, Ile leaue it with the next Quackſaluer, that with more skill ſhall doe him as little good.
sp.stage: Enter Gripe halting, Nice and Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Couſin Nice, and my man Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Shall I fetch you ſome drinke, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No. Thy mind runs all oth' pot.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: So 't had need, for you keepe mee Thirſty, ſpight o' my teeth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Goe you two to the vnder-Sheriffe; and bid him by vertue of this morgage, giue you poſſeſſion of Vasters lands. The beggerly ſlaue has broken with me, and Ile take the forfeit. Go quicke, quicke. I will not loſe an houre.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile but goe to the Church for a little holy-water—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be drownd in holy-water.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No, but a little ſprinkled Sir. We ſhall haue the better ſucceſſe in our buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I pree thee good Nice, diſpatch, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: I, come, come maſter Nice. There's good licour it h' houſe. You may ſprinkle your throte with that. Its better then holywater.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: One thing Sir. I do not like going to day. Sure tis not a luckie time. For the firſt Crow I heard this morning, cryed twice. This Euen, Sir, is no good number.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Poxe o' Crowes and numbers. If thou hadſt giuen her a peece of carrion, ſhe would ha' cryed againe. Away.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I go, Sir—ſtay, what if there be a Rauen about the ground?
Shall we then take poſſeſſion? Oh tis an vnluckie bird.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Why, let her croke the downfall of his houſe.
Whats that to me? prethee good Nice make haſte.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, too much haſte will make one ſtumble: and thats no good ſigne.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, Valentine, Haſt all things ready? how now—againe?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A toy comes in my head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Poxe o' that head: more toyes yet?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How if a Catte ſits on the Buttry hatch? Thou we'ſt proceed no further. My Grandam told me that a Cat ſitting on the hatch, was an ill ſigne.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Mew. Beate her off, daſh out her braines. Good Nice be not ſo curious.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh Sir, it's good doubting the worſt.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Are all things ready, Valentine? this foole troubles mee worſe then the gowte.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Sir, the remedie is verie painfull. I could giue a tedious courſe of phyſicke, worſe then any ſickneſſe. Keepe you faſting ſixteene dayes together, ſaue the dyet I giue you. Binde you to the poſt of patience euery day tenne houres; and haue one ſtill poure ſcaulding water on you: purge your very heart out: ſend your eyes out of their holes, to ſee how your feete doe: make your guttes barke worſe, then an hundred dogges at a beare-bayting. But my medicine is ſharpe and ſhort, but paſsing ſure. Sir, there be foure kindes of gowte.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No more of kinds. There's no gowte kind to any man, I thinke, but to Phyſicians. Your remedy ſhort-ſhort.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, nothing: ſpecially of no coſt. Do y' ſee this ten-penny naile?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Yes: What of that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This naile I muſt driue through your great toe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? through the bone?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, bone & fleſh too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh-oh-giue me my money. This medicine's worſe then any gowte. Oh good Valentine, your tent's too long—too long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then ſit and rot: be rack'd ſtill, Ile be gone.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine: would not a ſixe-penny naile ſerue?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You'l be Phyſician, will you? If you'l ſit downe and be cur'd, ſo: if not, farewell.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine:—euen do thy will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Endure it manfully. It's but a brunt—ſo. nailes him. You ſhall ſit but a quarter of an houre, till I ha' been at the Apothecaries, and then Ile looſe you. Now farewell, gowty foole, Thou took'ſt no purge, yet haſt a moſt ſharpe ſtoole. Pray heauens, this kill him not. Well, let him ſit. he takes away his purſe with his keis And this ſhal go with me. I pray Sr take your caſe. This plot has tooke; try if ſome new may hit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Come-come-Valentine. Oh-neuer was man ſo farre in my bonds, as I am in this Phyſicians. H' has nayl'd me to him. That euery whore in London, were but i' my caſe now. Why Valentine—
Oh he's come. How now? are you return'd? where's my morgage? out Villaines, where's my morgage? Oh my toe—oh my morgage. I'm vndone.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Me thinkes you are too faſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Plague o' you and your morgage. Oh my heart-it beats ſo, that it has broke my buttons. I would not bee ſo frighted againe to be made your heire. puffe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's the newes Thirſty? what, what, good Thirsty?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Let me vndoe you Maſter.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, not till I heare of my morgage. What's the matter? oh—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The matter? I would not ha' ſuch another croſſe, for all the croſſes i' your purſe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? oh—what? Is my morgage ſafe? Hath the vnder-Sheriffe done a miracle, and playd the honeſt man? what good Thirſty?

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, but a Hare croſs'd the way; and hee, poore timorous ſoule, durſt goe no further for feare of ſprights.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh rogues, pernicious villains, you conſpire to couzen me: get out the naile, Thirſty. Hares, and Rauens, and Diuels.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Who has abus'd you thus Sir? could you be ſo credulous, to thinke this a receyte good for the Gout? Sir, giue me leaue to helpe you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Do, good Ben. but not in this, Ben. not in this. Oh my morgage man, my morgage—run. I ſhall loſe a dayes fruits of my morgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come Sir, reſpect your health aboue your gaine.
I would not for your wealth haue halfe your paine.
Go in Sir, get ſome broth, looke to your wound.
Your morgage leaue to me, Ile keepe that ſound.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take my couſin Nice with you. Come Thirſty, helpe Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now for ſome cleanly tricke to ſhift my hands
Of this ſame ſhallow ſuperſtitious foole.
sp.p: Now couzen, I'am ſure you are not without an Erra Pater i' your pocket. They ſay this is like to be a very ſtrange yeare.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Moſt ſtrange, and full of prepoſterous, prodigious, turbulent, diſmall, fatall, amazing, terrifying—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Bleſſe vs. What?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Wonders. The effects whereof wil appeare in riſings, partly biformed, and partly circular, on mens forheads, and womens mountaines.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Is there no ſad mortality to enſue?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Yes, my Almanacke ſpeakes of a moſt fearefull peſtilence, eſpecially to happen amongſt Taylors and Gold-end-men.
Ther's a ſtatute-lace ſhall vndoe them ifayth. A Taylours Bill ſhal be no more ſo deadly as the plagues.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sirrah Nice, I had a dreame to night.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Paſſion o' my heart! a dreame? what? I do not like theſe dreames.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile tell thee what. Me thought, my troubled fancie
Led me into a Garden proudly deckt
With Natures glory, and the ſweeteſt flowers,
That ere my breath ſuck'd vp: where the greene graſſe
Tempted my ſleepy ſpirits to ſoft repoſe.
There came, me thought, a friend (dead now long ſince)
And ſhooke me by the hand, and queſtion'd me
Of many ſad euents, whoſe conference
So vex'd me that I woke. Why ſtand'ſt amaz'd?
Thou wilt not leaue me Coz.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, and you were ten Couſins. Dreame of a garden, and greene ruſhes, and a dead friends ſalutation? Couſin, make your will, be rul'd and make your will: you cannot liue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a foole of fate? who can
Preuent the deſtinie decreed for man? Ile on.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: So will not I. Good Coz, I leaue you to your deſtinie. The next newes I heare, the Lawyer's a dead man. Dreames quoth a! and he will not beleeue a dreame, he's an Infidell. One night I dream't that I found gold at a play. Next day I came thither, ſlatter'd with theſe hopes. Zlid, before the Prologue had done, I had loſt my purſe.
sp.l: Coz▪ if you ha'no faith in dreames, farewell.
I would not dreame of heauen, leſt I find hell.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This charme has caſt him off, now to my morgage.
Oh Vaster, thou art dead; thy hapleſſe iſſue,
Expos'd to the bleake ayre of theſe cold times.
I haue no meanes to expiate the wrongs,
My cruell Father, and my ſelfe more bloudy,
Haue done thee, but by charitie to thine,
All the poore pieces that remaine of thee.
So with the plaiſters of our broken good,
We hide the wounds, firſt hauing ſhed the bloud.
Within there Hoh.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou com'ſt vpon thy death, infectious iſſue of the worlds plague; if thy bloud ſtained foote enter theſe dores. Our parents are from home. Till their returne, Ile keepe poſſeſsion. Or loſe it with my life.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Incenſed Youth.
Thou fight'ſt 'gainſt power with a ſword of ſtraw:
As good cope with the diuell, as with the Law.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Me thinks, Sir, there ſhould dwell ſome pittie in your looke.
Oh, caſt an eye of mercie on the woes,
Of two moſt wretched Orphans; doubly loſt,
Firſt in their Parents miſeries: but, oh! moſt
In their vntimely deaths; for we doubt ſore,
We neuer ſhall behold their faces more.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My griefe requites you both.
No matter, had it ſo pleas'd the high powers,
If that my Father had excuſed yours.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, forget your ſtrength; and do not triumph ouer the proſtrate fortunes of two wretches,
sp.l: Expos'd to vnreſiſted tyrannie.
Behold a Mayden begging on her knee—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Riſe: that's heauens due. Theſe armes now thee intwine,
That wiſh for euer, to be called thine:
A ſtrange new influence runs through my affections,
Into my panting heart; and there inthron'd,
Commands my lower faculties to loue
This poore diſtreſſed Virgin. I am flam'd
With pittie and affection; whether more!
Yet let my ſenſes ſome coole reaſon gather:
What, loue the daughter, and haue ſlaine the father?
(I muſt: heauen knowes I muſt). See, my lov'd friends:
My comming to you is for other ends.
My Father ſent me to inuade your lands.
A while ſtand free redeemed with my hands.
There's money to relieue you: that done, you ſhall haue more.
Deſpaire not: heauen will not forſake the poore.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Right noble ſonne of ſo profeſt a foe,
Heauen be as kinde to you, as you t' our woe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I burſt, if I containe my paſsion. Faireſt Virgin,
If thou dar'ſt credite me, I loue thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hold. Here take your kindnes back: Though we are poore,
My ſiſter was not bred to be a whore.
Forbeare to touch her.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fond Youth, thy rage is vaine.
Th'art young: thy errour doth thy vertue ſtaine.
I loue her as a wife.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Oh doe not mock me.
How can I thinke, you to ſuch fortunes borne.
Will looke vpon a Mayd, ſo poore, forlorne?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alas! that pouerty ſhould vertue ſmother.
Not in my breſt. No, Ile ſtill honeſt be:
Vertue in rags are gold's all one to me.
Cenſure me both, as you ſhall finde me true,
Ile be your father, and your brother too.
sp.stage: Enter old Gripe brought in a chaire, by Nice and Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: So, let me downe, till I haue ſeene my new morgage.
How now ſon Beniamin, ha' you taken poſſeſsion?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Of that you cannot diſpoſſeſſe me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No knaue? what wilt thou take my lands before I'm dead?
You are a braue ſon indeed. But this is the world. If the father be poore, the ſonne would be ridde of him, to ſaue charges. If rich, he muſt haue his lands ere his bones be cold.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: They may be cold, for they ha' been rotten theſe dozen yeeres.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: I am very thirſty.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But dare not eate, becauſe I was dream'd to night of choking.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Now brother w' are, vndone.
The damned father will peruert the ſon.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gowt, dropſie, lameneſſe, rotten legges can haſten
T'vndoe the poore. Vſurers that ſit
Bound to their chaires with charms, & cannot moue
But by their porters, can to ill beſtirre them.
He needs make haſte, that is at hell before them.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha? for 3. Moneths?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Indeed Sir, by that power you put me in,
In charity to their miſerable ſtate,
Orphan'd of Parents, and of meanes to liue,
I gaue them 3. moneths profite of the lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out Villaine, Charitie's a begger, as thou wut be. 3. moneths! three weekes, 3. dayes, 3. houres had been more charity, then euer I ſhew'd, or will ſhew to ſuch beggers. Come Nice, Thirſty, liſt me: Ile take poſſeſsion my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope Sir, you'l not nullifie my deed.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Deed mee no deedes: Ile nullifie thee from being mine heire. Come, helpe me I ſay.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I dare not lift you againſt the poore.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Where's my man Thirsty?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He's gone in to drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh he's a good knaue: he has got poſſeſsion ot'h houſe.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Of nothing maſter but the Buttry, I.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: As lame as I am, Ile in my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sit ſtill you lethargie: y' had better drop—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Containe your ſelfe, young friend. He is my father,
Let not the warme neſt of my loue to you,
Hatch vp encouragement to my fathers wrongs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are my ſterne Sir, at your pleaſure guide
This tempeſt-beaten veſſell.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Good Sir confirme
This worke of pietie, which I preſum'd,
On faith of your good nature to affoord.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sirrah, your good nature will bring you to th'Almeſhouſe. Thou ſhalt not inherit a doyt of mine. And for you two Kitlins, Ile make you mew ith Iayle, and there be any law in England. So this chaſing fit hath got me the vſe of my legges agame. Oh excellent Surgion; would thou wert here againe, for the other 25. pounds.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Strange! that ſame Quack-ſaluer has done him good, againſt his will. How fare you Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The worſe for thee Baſtard. Th'haſt too much charitie in thee to be the ſonne of old Gripe.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Deare brother, yeeld poſſeſſion: wee 'l begge rather,
Then this our worthy friend ſhould loſe his father.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, be not ſo incens'd: reſume your ſonne
Into your former loue, and I reſigne
All right, that his free promiſe hath made mine.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Come then, Nice, Thirsty. Oh braue Surgion, I can goe.
Oh braue morgage I can enter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: M. Beniamin, a ſober word in priuate. If this wench want harbour, I care not if I giue her a nights lodging.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue inuited her with her brother to ſupper this night.
Will you—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh it's Fry-day, and I know you haue fleſh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou wouldſt take her any night. Is ſhe not fleſh?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sweet Couſin, I would not eate her. If you pleaſe to commend me to her: let me ſee, for what—I leaue that to you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Goe in, let me alone. This petulant foole.
Shall be my ſcaffold to erect my plots.
Come, friends, vnlode your ſorrowes on my heart.
Griefes weight is eas'd; when each one beares his part.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: THus am I ſtolne out from the Couent. Abbot,
Ly there, thou happy warranted caſe
Of any Villaine. Th'haſt been my ſtawking-horſe,
Now theſe ten months. So long 'tis ſince the Abbot
Went on a ſolemne pilgrimage and left
My brother, a good honeſt Fryer, his friend
Deputed for him. But my brother ſcarce
Warme in his new vice-honour, walking out
To viſite me one morning, at my houſe
Fell dead of an impoſtume ſuddenly.
I bury'd him in priuate; but from's bloud
Am purer then the Cryſtall. Studying now,
How to turne ſorrow into policie,
I haue aſſum'd his ſhape. Who can deny,
But that a Dunce may riſe to Dignitie?
Blind Ignorance doth not alwaies ſtrut in Sattin.
It often walkes a Clergy pace in blacke,
And deales the holy Rites with as bold hands,
As if it graſp'd Ioues thunder: and did iudge it
Enough to ſtare, looke bigge, and with a brow
More rugged then is Radamanths, denounce
Torrors againſt ill deeds: the whiles their owne
Are not leſſe monſtrous, but leſſe broadly ſhowne.
Thus in my ſelfe, how eaſie't is, I proue,
To ſweat out iudgements 'gainſt the ſins we loue.
As if a garment of world-couzning grace
Were impudently good, ſet out by place.
Well, I get nothing by this borrow'd forme,
But countnance to my thefts. This hollow tree
Keeps all my holineſſe: Lie there Abbot, till
My worke is done, then doe thou hide my ill.
Maſſe heres comes one already.

sp.speaker: Valent.
sp.p: Now haue I, like a Paraſite, couerd my backe with braines. Out of my vſurers Gowtie toe, I haue ſpun a faire ſuite. I would faine heare, whether the diuell be dead or no. Yet I need not be ſo inquiſitiue, for I'm ſure he has giuē me nothing in'swill. Now am I in queſt of ſome vaulting houſe. I would faine ſpend theſe crownes, as I got them, in cony-catching. I ha'the game in ſent, & will follow it with full cry.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand—Giue the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Word? what word? am I beleaguerd?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Few words are beſt among friends. Emptie your pockets, and you may vault the lighter. Quicke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Th'art an honeſt fellow, a very honeſt fellow. In good faith I had no great need of mony; but ſince thou haſt brought me ſome, Ile not refuſe it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Troth, I ha'but a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith nor I. we'll euen draw cuts, who ſhall ha'both.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed.—Shall we breathe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good fortune grant, you be able to pay me for this paines. In ſadnes, I deſerue double fees.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile make you plead harder, ere you ſit downe to tell your money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Looke that your caſe be good, I ſhall picke a hole in't elſe.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Well, let the law paſſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not altogether ſo: leſt we be both hange.—Stand your ground. Zlid, I cannot abide theſe running Cockes.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I haue ſeene a runner winne the battell.—Shall wee draw ſtakes?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha? a match—Throw by weapons, and lets embrace.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I am a villaine, but I feare your clutch worſe then a Seriants

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
As I'm true theefe, thou maiſt truſt me. Ha ſirrah!
Robin Hood, and the Pindar of Wakefield had not a ſtiffer bout. Shall we cling, like a couple of Eeles, not to bee diſſolu'd but by Thunder?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Moſt liberally. Let's ſet vp ſhop together.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Done: & to begin our trade, behold a cuſtomer. Stand cloſe.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: This ruſſet-ſhape of a plaine-dealing yeoman
Spirits my hopes with boldneſſe. Sharpe ſuſpition
Like to a winking Iuſticer ſhall ſee me,
And yet not ſee me. Thus with griefe-ſwolne eyes,
Ile match my wife, and childrens miſeries.
This fiftie pound Ile husband like a Badger;
Buy and ſell Barley: and ſo eaſily wind
Into the preſent paſſages of Bedford.
How good a ſchoolemaſter is Pouertie!
I could not liue on hundreds, that came in
By annuall rents; now I begin to thriue
On the ſmall fragments. Thus like Prodigals,
That once did ſcorne the meate, now glad of pottage.
The mannor gone, Ile trie to liue oth' cottage.
Bedford, ha'for you.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand. Giue the word.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: The word, y' are a theefe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You might ha'ſhot twice, and not hit it righter.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: What do you ſhoot at?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Oh Sir, like your Ieſuite, all at the purſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you caſt out the diuell, and ſaue's a coniuring.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Are you ſo cunning at the blacke Art? Ile trie your skill. What, both at once? that's no faire play.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Faire play is for Fencers. Yet thou ſeemſt a good fellow. Thou ſhalt haue it. Stand aſide, partner.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Saiſt thou me ſo, boy? then there's mony, win't and wear't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Now could I get in and rob 'hem both—Hercules! Hee laies about him like Orlando Furioſo, or a coward turnd deſperate. Braue boy yfaith. Wee might ha'robd two and twenty Taffata-clok'd rorers, before this freeſe-iacket. Oh, your ſurly Bore is like
a bloudy'd Maſtiffe: when your ſpruce Pantaloun bawles like a whelpe in a Tauerne: yet at the ſight of cold yron runs, as if he had ſeene a Serieant.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Hold, hold: Keepe your caſh.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: The mony's good mony Sir, if it be not too heauy for you

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nay, for the weight I could make ſhift, but for the ſcuruy conditions goe with it.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Hau you any gall to't Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not not ſo much as pigeon. Put vp thy caſh my braue quinteſſence of Hobbniols. Giue me thy hand. How many thouſand cudgels haſt thou broken i' thy daies about a May-pole?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I warrant, as many as would make all Bedford chimnies ſmoke a whole winter.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Ieſt on. Ha' you any more to ſay to me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nothing my braue Clem o' th Clough, but I would thou wouldſt deale with vs. Say, ſhall wee put all our ſtockes together, and ſet out a ſhip of our owne?

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Ha? firſt tell me truly what you are.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Let's ſit downe to counſell. I am the Abbot of Newnham.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: How? much?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile not bate you an Ace on't, till the old Abbot returnes from Pilgrimage. My chamber ſhall be our Rendeuous. The diuell himſelfe in the ſhape of a blurting Conſtable wil not looke for vs there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am a ſouldiour, and in this vacation time am forc'd to do like Lawyers; when ſuites do not make them, they make ſuites: becauſe the warres will not maintaine me, I maintaine the warres. I ſet vp my Bils in Bedford here, for a Phyſician, and dealt with Gripe for the Gowt. I haue a proiect to ſwell our purſes till they burſt. Will you ſecond me?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: As inſeparably, as a condition does an obligation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I haue often heard the gripulous Dotard talke of Fairies: and how rich the houſe proues that they haunt. I haue ripened the bliſter of his imagination to the full. Shall we launce it? I haue keys that ſhall ſecure our conueyance. Is't a match?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: The ſafeſt ſtratagem we could deuiſe,
By craft, more then by ſtrength, all theeues do riſe.
Of many politicke knaues you cannot ſpie one.
The Foxe will haue his prey before the Lion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Two or three nights we'le ſcatter ſome ſmall peeces of ſiluer, till opportunitie plumpe our proiect.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: I take it rightly. Oh tis quicke and ſharpe.
So with a Gudgeon loſt, we'll catch a Carpe. A bootie.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: As I was ſaying, Maſter Bromley, why ſhould you take th' aduantage of your neighbour Sager here? Y' haue got the reuerſion of his Leaſe. Ther's is but one life to come in't. Wee are all mortall. It may come ere you looke for't. I loue peace, I loue peace.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I ſay, that life is forfeit: and Ile enter on all. The law is on my ſide. Ile not be bound to th' peace.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Nay Sir, Ile bind no man: but if I could perſwade you—to be fleeced both, ſo I might be kept warme in your wooll—How ſay you neighbour Sager?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Alas Sir, I do but defend my owne.
Nay could be wel-contented to ſit downe
With ſome (though vniuſt) loſſe. I iudge it beſt.
Though with ſome preiudice to buy my reſt.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Therein you wrong your ſelfe: the law is impartiall, like a Bell, as ſound on one ſide, as on th' other, if the clapper be right. Maſter Bromley a word—What will you iudge me worthy of, If I perſwade him to relinquiſh his right? You know your caſe—.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's twenty angels: worke it good Maſter Griffin, work it; and you ſhall be my euerlaſting Atturney. But if you faile, you muſt returne.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Piſh, neuer talke o' that man—Mr. Sager, a word—I loue peace, though I cannot liue by't. I reſpect my conſcience aboue my purſe—when t' has no money in't.—What will you giue mee to draw Bromley to a good handſome compoſition?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Not a pennie, till y' haue done't.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: You know twill go againſt you, but I loue peace.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: (I neuer knew't in any of your Tribe.
Th' euent be what it will, Ile giue no bribe.)
Sir, as I like your end—God and my cauſe,
Are coate of ſteele, gainſt the ſharpe fangs of lawes.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Shall we walke on? our iourney's long.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Not ſo long as you take't. Stand, good Mr. Lawyer, ſhall I puta caſe to you now?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Come, vntruſſe, we haue haſt of buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Quicke ſirrah, I ſhall ſerue an Execution o' your throte elſe

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Indeed Gentlemē, I am ſorry that I'm not better ſtored for you. If you had tooke me comming from terme, I could haue ſerued your turnes better.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Bind them, hamper the rogues. Serue a Habeas corpus on that fieri facies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: How happy were this common wealth! how ſound!
If euery corrupt Lawyers fingers were thus bound.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sager, I know thee poore: here take thy purſe.
Though I rob theſe, no poore man ſhall me curſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry till I lay the Lawyer in the midſt of his clients.
Are your talons bound Harpy? Thou lieſt now like a Stallion new gelt, betwixt two Mares. This is a Diſtring is, ſirrah.
Farewell pettie-fogger.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh neighbours, I'am vndone, vndone.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Then helpe to vndoe me. Ile haue my action againſt the Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Stay till you catch them maſter Bromley.
Well, ſomwhat this my falling ſtate releeues:
That honeſty ſpeeds well euen amongſt theeues

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe. Good maſter Griffin, your breath's ſtrongeſt, yawle, yawle. Your tongue could neuer ſtand your Clients in more ſtead.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I heard this way ſome mans diſtreſſed voyce,
Crying for helpe: ſome robbery. Oh tis no wonder!
A theefe and bawdy houſe are ne're farre aſunder.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh good woman helpe, helpe to vntie vs.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: I know 'hem all. Two knaues, one honeſt man.
They know not me in this tranſlation.
Come Sir, Ile looſe you firſt, helpe you the reſt.
Do well to all, but to the good do beſt.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh that I had the villaines vpon an execution now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Would you turne hang-man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: I faith ſweet wench, I would ſhew 'hem the law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh pitie them: neceſſitie has no law.
Perhaps want forc'd them; though it was not good.
What Horſeleaches are they, that full, ſucke blood!
There is an Inne, enter, refreſh your ſelues.
Their loſſe is money, yet I mone their ſtate.
Who pities me moſt, moſt vnfortunate!
Robd of a husbands loue, now of himſelfe.
How farre is this beyond all loſſe of pelfe!
He ſold me hither; may that ſinfull price
Of my deepe ſorrow neuer preiudice
His happineſſe, what climate euer holds him.
Be bleſt, ſweet husband; let my ruine buy
Thy wiſhd content, though I forſaken die.
This witch has tyr'd me with her cuſtomers,
Whom I haue all ſent home with betterd minds.
Againſt her vicious will, I force her ſtriue
By vertue rather, then by luſt to thriue.
I know, I am expected.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The Iackes be now vncag'd, and flutterd hence.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: (The woman, that releaſd them, I ſhould know.
She frees them from this bondage to a worſe.
There is no theefe, like whore, to picke the purſe.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Shall we not ſhift ground?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: By no meanes. A theefes ſafeſt reſidence is in the ſame plat he did the robberie. There, of all places, the Cuckoldly hue will neuer crie after him.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: When ſhall we ſhare the booties, and be proud,
How liberally our diuiſion mounts?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The daies worke done, we'l caſt vp the accounts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where's the pettie-foggers Portmanteau?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lay't there. So, you ſhall ſee me catch a fat Pickerell, with this Gudgeon preſently. Stand cloſe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle, I had a certaine ſcuruy dreame to night.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Dreame? what of dreames? good couſin be not ſo nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I dreamt—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Be you hang'd, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Behang'd both, except I may haue ſome drinke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Me thought I found a great deale of money.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I would we had it, couſin, without dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Whoop maſter—no part of my finding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No matter for a part: all's mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for finding: and Ile keep't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Soft, ſirrah: it lies there for a wager.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What wager, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Marry, that who euer finds it, ſhall looſe all the money in's purſe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ile ha' no part in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Iudgement, Gentlemen: ha' they not loſt the wager?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Vaſt. Loſt, loſt; as ſure as Virginitie; no ſooner laid then loſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come then to pay, to pay. (Sure this is Gripe, my Bedford-Gowtie-Vſurer. Plague o▪ your ſtilts; what Carpenter ſet 'hem vpright? not my wimble, I hope.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh I am ſpoyld, ſpoyld; this tis to dreame of ſinding money—I knew, what twould come to.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Saue your labour, good maſter Theefe: for my breeches are ith' faſhion, a great deale of pocket, but no lining.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: This is the rocke that ſplit me. Oh good fate!
That thou hadſt now about thee halfe my ſtate.
Is't ſinne to rob the Theefe? by vſurious courſe,
He once robd me, now I rob him by force.
No difference but this, twixt him and me.
I ha' not ſuch protection, as had he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh I am a poore man, a verie poore man.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Thou art indeed; wealth without vſe doth free
No ſoule from the bleake ſtormes of pouertie.
Who cannot natures requeſts ſatisfie
Out of his wealth, his coffer's rich, not he.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Be they all bound to the good forberance?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Thus farre quits my reuenge. The Vſurer lies,
As faſt in mine, as I am in his tyes.
Now let me kill him. No, bloud ſhall not die
My other ſinnes in purple. Lye there. Loe!
That the wiſe lawe would ſerue all vſurers ſo.
How few in thy bonds didſt thou ere vntie?
Now bound thy ſelfe, ſo without mercy lie.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Come, let's retire to our refuge.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle. I would this all were but a dreame too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Oh coz, I am damnd, damnd, my mony's gone.
Elſtow morgage is loſt. Wallow to me, Nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh vncle, its dangerous tumbling, ſnakes i' the graſſe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Wallow to me, Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Maſter, I'm ſo drie, I cannot ſtirre my feet.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Helpe.—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: More robberies yet? tis ſtrange, how villains ſwarme!
Miſchiefes hold cloſe to keepe each other warme.
Three ranke corruptions make their neere abode.
An Abby, Bawd'houſe, and a Theeuiſh rode.
Where be theſe men diſtreſſed?—how? my Vſurer?
Shall I vnbind him, that hath bound my husband
In mercileſſe fetters? Yes, I'm bidden, ſtill;
With good deeds to requite my enemies ill.
Come, diuell, Ile vnloſe thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Oh how I'm croſt!
My mony, and my morgage, all, all loſt.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Maſſe, a prety wench—If ſhe lay thus bound before mee, I would not looſe her, but vpon ſome conditions.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: VVill you go in Sir, and refreſh your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ile follow thee, ſweete girle. Would I could cope This morgage, though my other be paſt hope.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Doe they brew wine here?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: See how this woman ſtill me quits, and croſſes.
I rob and binde, and ſhe releeues their loſſes.
Why doth ſhe thus? Its but a tricke of hers:
By charitie to draw in cuſtomers.
I am now patient, but more Cuckold ſtill.
I helpe her to ſupply, gainſt my owne will.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Shall we retire to my chamber, and ſhare?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry. Here comes another Iack-daw: let's plucke him, and take his feathers with vs—ſtand.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou durſt not ſay ſo, were we on iuſt tearmes.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: You ſhould bee ſome Lawyer, you ſtand ſo on your termes
Faith, we muſt change profeſſions with you, you muſt giue's our fees.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Youle earne them firſt?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Braue Sir, ſo do not Lawyers alwayes.
But when you'r payd your ſelfe, you'l giue's our due.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hold, Gentlemen, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Thine, noble Valoys? thou ſhalt begge hisranſome then.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Hee ſtands ſecure. Haſte to your chamber. There Ile meet you preſently, and then wee'l ſhare.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Are thy ends good in this giuen libertie?
Or doſt it here alone to murder me?

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Not with my ſword, but with a tale ſhall wound thy amazed heart—come, let's ſit downe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What tale? good friend, be plaine and ſhort.
Woe to a heart, by expectation centuples the ſmart.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: I haue commendations to you from one Vaster: For by's deſcription you ſhould be the man.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Liues Vaster then?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: 'Las Sir, you know he's dead.
And by your bloudy hand was murdered.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By me?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Is not your name Sir Beniamin Gripe!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: You kill'd him, Sir. Poore man he dy'd
With penitence to heauen, to you remiſsion.
Sayd, that you did it like a man, prouok'd
By his intemperate rage. Fate gaue that I
Keeping his walke, came to cloſe vp his eye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Heauen pardon me. What ſayd the dying Vaſter?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: He charg'd me ſeeke you out, and gaue me gold,
To bury him in ſecret; leſt his death
Should hazard yours, and charm'd my ſilent breath.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: His loue giues fire to my greene pile of ſorrowes.
May his bones reſt in peace: in griefe I liue;
Leſſe he and heauen do my blacke fault forgiue.

sp.speaker: Vaſter.
sp.l: He hath forgiuen you, only this he begges;
That to the ſcatter'd pieces of himſelfe,
Left to ſuruiue his miſeries vncomplete,
His Widow and his Orphans, you would yeeld
Some pittie for your owne, heauens, and his ſake:
And teach that hand, (from which he hop'd ſome good)
To ſuccour theirs, that tooke away his blood.
He bad me tell you, now all meanes were gone,
To expiate that ſinne, ſaue only one:
To hold thoſe vp, that on the worlds ſea ſwimme:
Since he had them vndone, you vndone him.
That you would be to them, as he ſhould be:
This he bequeath'd you as a Legacie.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile be a iuſt Executor of his will.
Good friend, great thankes: my purſe th'haſt ſpar'd to ceaz
But what is worſe, haſt robb'd me of my peace.
Ʋaſter, th'art dead: if thy transformed ſoule,
Could from the battlements of you high Tower,
Behold the vow'd endeuours of my heart,
To ſatisfie thy will and my huge debt,
In thee, to thine, thou wouldſt my merit ſet
'Mongſt thy beſt friends: yet narrow are my bounds;
To giue them plaiſters, that firſt gaue them wounds.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Farewell Sir, thinke on Vaſter.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Friend adieu. To Vaſter and my vowe I will be true.
How thicke the ſharpe pulſe of my conſcience beares!
How ſtrangely my diſtracted Phantſie threats!
Oh vnappeaſed murder, that ſtill keepes
The ſenſitiue committer from faſt ſleepes:
And murmurs in the eares a fatall knell
Of reſtleſſe thoughts on earth, of worſe in hell,
How deepe thou ſtrik'ſt me with a ſilent blow!
Be patient heart, to thy fate humbly bow.
Fetch him againe I cannot; oh his ſowne
Is too too mortall. Why then hurl'd I downe
My ſinking ſpirits? Let me ſlye to mirth,
And burden cares with wine, to make them ſinke.
The worlds rule is, Who feels the lode of conſcience let him drink.
But oh importunate griefe! too hard it is,
To counterfet a falſe and forged bliſſe!
Yet once Ile force a tryall; I haue here an Inne,
I heare and wonder, is turn'd houſe of ſinne.
Ile ſee, if the looſe ſprawles, with their ſharpe wit,
Can giue my mind a medicine for this fit.
Whores I abhorre, as Gardiners Iayes: no matter;
Once for experiment, Ile heare them chatter.
sp.p: Preuention! I thinke here's one of the iourney-women come, to proffer me her ſeruice. Black proſtitution! that any ſuch face ſhould euer waite vpon thee. Siſter, what ſeeke you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What is hard to find:
An honeſt man, or els my eyes are blinde.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fut, if I ſay I'm one, I then fall ſhort,
Of the occaſion I intend for ſport.
I'm ſuch a foole in this Priapus-rode.
sp.p: Mee thinks, ſweet-heart, your honeſt-man ſhould bee one, that ſhould pleaſe your appetite, ſtirre your veines, tickle your bloud, and make you laugh delight into your panting ſpleene.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: An honeſt diuell.
Th'are friends to hell, that tempt weake ſoules to euill.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, let me kiſſe thee—ſo: this was with eaſe;
Words are ayry ſhades, th'are deeds that pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, do not thinke to enter my chaſte fort,
Encourag'd by this parle. You preſume—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not to vnlocke thy treaſures with ſuch keyes.
Gold only can ſurpriſe ſuch holds as theſe.
And I haue that will doo 't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then vſe it well.
How's wealth abus'd, when it conducts to hell!
Sir, I will ſet no price on your deſires.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Ile be the franker Pay-maſter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You muſt: Then pay me for my vertue: ſo Ile▪ take it.
What ſtarues luſt, is well bought; not what it feedes.
'Tis follies dregges, with coyne to buy ill deedes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, come; why ſhould you be ſo quaint, and nice,
That know what belongs to 't? 'Dsſo, a Virgin
At thirteene, or perhaps a little vnder,
Could not with whuling nay's be ſo peruerſe,
In her beworded Mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I muſt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou doſt not rightly of my merits deeme.
I would not know you ſuch, as you now ſeeme.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The golden footed law, that goes or runs,
Staies, and turnes backe, as we giue motion to it,
Shall ſtep the paſe, which thou would'ſt haue it. Nay,
Speake as thy tongue inſtructs it. I will change
Thy pouerty to gold, rich robes, a Coach,
And prauncing Courſers, that ſhall whirle thee through
The popular ſtreets; and when thou ſitſt in pride,
The tamed law ſhall lacquay by thy ſide.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Theſe are ſome incitations to a heart
Tainted with malice, or that thinkes a heauen
In glorious oſtentation; or would ſtand
Affected with the bane of prurient luſt.
I'm of another temper. Pray you leaue me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt Nectar drinke:
Make ebrious waſte of the ſweet Gnoſſian wines;
Feſants ſhall be courſe dyet: refin'd marow,
Small pounded nuts, and loſſeng'd Amylum,
Scrap'd pearle and date-ſtones ſprinkled on each ſlice,
And ſtrew'd with ſugar, like white froſt on yce.
Grant me but loue, Ile raine a ſhowre of Gold
Into thy lappe, out-ſhining Ioue, when he
Wrapt in his glory courted Danae.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thy language does affright me. Oh my ſtarres!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O let not teares ſpoile ſuch a beauty. Tell mee; Why ſpill you water like a Crockodile, to captiue mee; that might haue don't with mirth, nimbler then ayre?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I haue no deſire,
To take your luſt, but pittie. Some what prompts my credulous heart, there is ſome goodneſſe in you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: My truth ſhall quite thy faith, Impart thy mind.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile truſt you, Sir. I am a wretched woman,
The widow or the wife, I know not whether, of the diſtreſſed or dead Vaſter.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How? I faint to tell thee; thou art then a widow:
The warres haue ended his infortunate dayes.
Nay, let not griefe oppreſſe thy ſpirits. Oh,
I haue kill'd the wife and husband with one blow.
Lift vp thy ſowning eyes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh let me dye. Rather ſhort death, then lingring miſerie.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Reuiue thy heart: Vaſter yet liues in me:
I am his ſonne, that hath thy husbands lands.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And can I looke for mercy at your hands?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Receiue this earneſt; all my ſtate is thine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You cannot with theſe ſpels charme me to ſinne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I do not: when I taint thy chaſter eares
With motions of blacke luſt, pronounce me Villaine.
Tell me, who brought you to this Brothell-Inne?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He, to whom heauen (I truſt) hath clear'd all ſin.
My Vaſter ſold me hither. I was content.
Thus to relieue his ſtate, when all was ſpent.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But couldſt thou liue infectleſſe in this ayre?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I haue, and will.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will? This giues ſtrange ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I made a promiſe, that without conſent
Of her that bought me, I would not depart.
See where th' Inchantreſſe comes.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Now minion, you muſt be gadding. Cry you mercie, Land-lord: if you'l haue any ſport, walke in, walke in. You ſhall take out your rent here, Land-lord. She ſhall be your own Vacation and Terme too, Land-lord.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So, you pernicious Damme of luſts foule littour,
You that buy beauty and do ſell 't againe;
And liue by th'occupation. Heare you? Free
This woman from your brothell ſlauerie.
Or I ſhall bring you to the cart and laſh.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Oh I am caſt away; ſhe coſt me fifty pounds, I ne're got foure grotes by her yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt loſe more by keeping her. Goe cleanſe the houſe from this diſorder, or I here diſcharge thee.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Good Land-lord, beſtow her where you will. I am content to be rid of her, ſo I may hold your fouour—
sp.l: Foxe pull your honeſty. Is this the dancing mayde?
One more ſuch purchaſe will vndoe my trade.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hoſtice, Oſtice, wher's your kinſwoman?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yonder Sir, talking with my Land-lord, your Worſhips ſonne.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Son Benlamin? yea faith, are you ſo cloſe with a wench? Come hither—ſhe's a whore, Take heed on her.
sp.l: If ſhe want mennes, bring her home: ſhe ſhall keep my houſe.
Faith, I grow old, and cannot now long liue:
Oh ſuch a Wench would be reſtoratiue
Perſwade her Ben.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt, Sir▪ See,
The pleaſed fates conſent to ſuccour thee.
My fathers houſe ſhall ſhelter thee vnknowne.
Pleaſe the old man with words, but hold your owne.
If my plot takes, as I can hope no leſſe,
This luſt of his ſhall thy good fortunes bleſſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: COme, ſiſter to my ſorrowes, and my ſelfe.
They ſay, ſociety in woes doth lighten
Our preſſures; but I finde the contrary.
My woes are heauier by thy companie
My griefe for thy diſtreſſe, doubles mine owne.
I ſhould be farre leſſe wretched, if alone.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sweet brother. ſince we muſt both ſuffer, thinke it ſome comfort, that we ſhare an equall fortune.
sp.l: Griefe has leſſe power to worke on our ſad hearts;
Where mutuall loues contend to beare their parts.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Little once thought thy mother, that thy fate
Should ſtoope to ſeruice to relieue thy ſtate:
We are not try'd, but in our miſerie.
He is a cunning Coach-man that can turne
Well in a narrow roome. To manage plenty
In a right forme, commends the ſtate, not perſon.
Hee's bleſt, that to be rich can giue conſent
With honeſtie, or reſt poore with content.
I wonder, Benjamin doth not viſit vs.
His laſt reliefe is done, if that ſpring drye,
We faint for ſuccour, and muſt fainting dye.
sp.p: See, here comes Bromloy, once our fathers Steward: Sure, hee'l ſupport vs. Siſter, cry his kindneſſe: thy ſpeech is more pathetical.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Theeues, Lawyers, Rogues, Harlots, and Inne-keepers, are mens purgations. Griffin has cheated mee: tooke twenty angels from me; theeues tooke 'hem from him. He promis'd to draw Sager to compound; now the day's gone againſt me.
sp.l: Oh I could wiſh my nailes turn'd Vulturos tallons,
That I might teare their fleſh in mammocks, raiſe
My loſſes from their carcaſes turn'd Mummy.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, a word—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now Kitlin, what would you haue?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, remember we are the miſerable children of loſt Ʋaster; whom once you ſeru'd.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What's that to me?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you can ſpare ſomewat to vs diſtreſſed.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: This is plaine begging. Minion, fall to worke,
And earne ſupply to wants with diligent labour.
For Vaſters ſake I will not vrge the Statute.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The Statute, Iudas? w' are no Beggers, though
We try'd thy courteſie. Curſed be thy fate,
Thou from our father gott'ſt thy whole eſtate.
sp.p: Yet grudgeſt vs ſome fragments. Hence, out Dogge: If thou ſtay'ſt miſcreant—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Boy, Ile ſmoke you for't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Do thy worſt, diuell. An inſatiate worme ſtrike deepe into thy conſcience, ſile thy heart ſtrings with rubbing flets: And turne thy derogated name,
sp.l: On foggy blaſtings of eternall ſhame.
Ingratitude is gone; and in his roome,
Extortion and a fiend is hith or come.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'm going to ſee my morgage—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, ſhew mercy on two wretched Orphans.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out beggers, mercie? what doſt talke to me of mercy? I'm going to let my grounds. I haue no leaſure for mercy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Goe thou accurſed Cain: in miſerie,
When thou begg'ſt mercy, be't as farre from thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, y' have vndone our Parents; pittie vs.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay to heare you, I haue buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Heauen be as deafe to thee, when thy ſoule breath
Shall begge ſome reſpite at thy violent death.
This fellow ſure will ſuccour vs.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Iune, Iuly, August, September—the firſt day—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, raiſe our proſtrate fortunes with ſome helpe: Some little helpe, you know vs.

sp.speaker: N • c.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember I haue ſeene you. Let's ſee—The fourteenth day—bad. I muſt do no deed of charitie to day; I haue preſident for it. 't is loſt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now I remember, when I went to ſchoole,
I read of one Veſpaſian a good Emperour,
That told his Courtiers if a day out-ſlipt him,
Wherein he did nor good, that day was loſt.
The next he would redeem't with double coſt.
Ill colour'd ſinne, how ſhamefull doſt thou looke,
In them that plead thy warrant from their booke!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Fourteenth day. A good turne forgotten. Oh heres learning from the ſtarres.
sp.l: Though I do little good ere I am rotten,
Like citizens, I would not ha't forgotten.
Yet let me ſtudy on't: though a man may not giue, he
May buy, I hope without danger. Faire ſiſter,
What ſhall I giue you for your maiden-head?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thus much: a broken head.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh—Oh—Forgiue me, good Calender—I perceiue now, thy counſel's true. It's an euil day indeed: I ſhould neither haue bought nor ſold on't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence, skie-conſulting Gypſie: men commit
Sinnes darke as night, and blame the ſtarres for it.
Another paſſenger—Oh this is Sager.
His wife was once a ſeruant to our mother.
Alas, when theſe built from our ruinous woe
Releeue vs not, what ſhould this poore man doe.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: I long to heare from London; how my ſuite
Ends, or depends: if loſt, I'm loſt with it.
Who would truſt any barres this tottring world
Can plot to fortiſie our wheeling ſtates!
When the ſtrong dores of Iuſtice may be broke,
Or lifted from the hinges by the force
Of politike engines: or the ſafeſt locke
Be pickt with a falſe key.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, dwels there any mercie in your heart?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Yes: or of mercy, I muſt hope no part.
I know you, and your wants. My wife was once your Parents ſeruant.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: True, but that time is paſt,
And in her ſeruice now I would be plac't.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: That were too lauiſh yeelding to your woe.
I am but poore, troubles haue made me ſo,
Yet of that ſmall life-blood, which my drencht ſtate
H'as left it by the Lawes ſharpe ſurgerie,
Embrace a portion, as your needs require;
And I may giue. Here comes your enemies Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue bene ſeeking all you three with nowes.
Good newes; friend Sager, the day's yours.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: It's welcome. I haue the better meanes to ſuccour theſe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You haue preuented my requeſt: I purpos'd
To beg that kindneſſe of you. Robin, I would
Intreat you to accept my ſeruice, but
I meane the name of it: for in deed Ile vſe thee
As my moſt equall and reſpected friend.
Nan, in thine armes I throw and locke my ſelfe;
My fortunes be all thine: the key's thy loue;
Let this kiſſe be the ſeale. Ye ſacred powers
Make indiſſoluble this knot of ours.
Now, maſter Sager, giue her that reſpect,
You would my wife: all charges are my debt.
sp.p: Robin, you know the houſe; conduct your ſiſter thither; that done, conucy theſe letters to the widdow Sorrow; (that's her borrowed name) ſhe lies at my fathers.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: With iuſt hands.
I'm prouder of thy loue, then of thy lands.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Oh pure quinteſſence of thy profeſſion.
How many haſt thou robd, thus to make vp
Thy perfect godneſſe! as if wiſer nature
Had made an extract of ten thouſand Lawyers,
And thriſe refin'd it with immortall fires:
Then ſet it like a ſanctified Lampe
On th' Altar of thy ſoule; to giue exemplar light,
In the dull darkeneſſe of this ſinne-borne night.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Bromley's growne mad with rage: I'm iealous of him. You know the hopes of your poſteritie dwell on your preſent fortunes: all which burne with the ſhort Taper of your ſingular life, Say he ſhould quench it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: How Sir? murder me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I cannot tell, it's but my iclaouſie.
Tis not amiſſe, to keepe preuentions eye
Open and wary. Inſtruments of death
Stand ready preſt to a malicious arme.
And policie, like a cunning Ieſuite,
Watches behind that Arras for a call.
The deed once done, helpe it who can, or ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What ground for this ſuſpition find your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The fury of his madneſſe, Enuies ſome,
That ſurges from the poyſon'd auarice
Of his ſwolne heart: his broken reſolutions,
Wherein his traitor-tongue can ſcarce forbeare
The proteſtation. Giue me leaue to feare.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What will you counſell me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That muſt be ſtudy'd. Thus—Liſten—We'll trie what miſcheefes he can warpe: With woodden waſters learne to play at ſharpe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh my backe, my backe—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh ſonne, ſonne, worſe then euer. The Gowt was but a ſtitch to this. Oh the Collicke, the Collicke and ſtone.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: There be two of them maſter, aske the widdow elſe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sure it will rend my bowels out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's iuſt: The ſtone ith' bladder now ſhould make him ſmart That has ſo long bene ſicke of ſtone ith' heart.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh that I knew where my old Phyſician liu'd.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Keepe on your habite. Our walke's turn'd Pouls, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Zlid, if our third party were here, wee would venter on 'hem all. Th'are but welſh freeze; they would ſhrinke at the ſenſe of yron.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Let's muffle vp our villaines with the ſhadow
Of ſome great conference: if a cheate be offer'd,
We'll not refuſe: but now to compaſſe it,
Muſt not be done by force of armes, but wit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Sonne Beniamin, you muſt to Goldington,
To view yong Bruſters lands: th'are offer'd me
This morne in morgage. Harke you—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Thirſty, come hither.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Ha'you any drink there?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but come drinke thy ſelfe drunke with Poetrie.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Faith, Poetrie now a daies will ſcarce make a man drink. I had as liefe be a pot as a Poet: then I ſhould ſometimes be full of good liquour.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, your Poet is too full of that, it makes him thred bare. Sirrah, I ha'made a Sonnet here to my Miſtreſſe; ſhe n'ere wrought ſuch a one on her Samplar. Lay thine eare cloſe to my muſicall tongue, I ſhall rauiſh her.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You ſhall be hang'd for't then.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Open thine eares, like an Oyſter a ſunning

l.hi: Euen as the bird, which we Camelion call, doth liue on aire for aye:
So my kinde heart, euer like a stocke-Doue ſhall feede on thy loue all day.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: I, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I, and all night too: but that night would make the verſe too long. Now I talke of night, let me ſee what time of day it is. I haue buſineſſe, muſt not be rim'd away.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Pray y' Sir, how ſpeakes your watch? One? mine lies inclining to two You haue a prettie interpreter of the time there. Who made it, French or Dutch? You need not doubt me, Sir, I am the new Parſon of Saint Peters in Bedford.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sir, then as I may ſay, haue ioy in your new Benefice, for belly-peece you muſt ha'none. Pray' lets peruſe your watch, ſee you mine.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Fezz 'Sir, y' haue a braue waſh there. Chill warrant the Kings waſh-maker made it. Beſeech you mozter Nice, let me ſee maſter Parſon waſh. Maſter Paſon will you zell your waſh, chill giue you good caſh for it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, my honeſt friend, I will not ſell it.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Will you runne with me for it?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Runne? no.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Cheuore ye runne for't, you ſhall nere ha't elſe.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Oh my watch—Nic. Oh my watch.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stop the theefe, ſtop the theefe.
sp.stage: Vaſter runs away with Curfews watch: Curfew with Nices.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stop the Prieſt, ſtop the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Let him go, he runs for a wager.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How now? is my couſin Nice playing at Bace?
I know one of them well, by his ſad tale
Of Vaſters death: for that Ile not purſue him.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Son, I did reſt me, hoping to go forward.
But ſo increaſe my paines, I am not able.
Suruey you Bruſters lands, and ſpeed returne.
All's for your good, for I am now out-worne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I goe Sir—All's for me; yet whileshe liues,
And his hydroppicke ſpirits can looke through
His bodies loope-holes, and conuey the pleaſure
Of his contemplate gold, his luſts ſole God,
Through thoſe windowes to th' admiring heart:
Nothing comes from him; not the ſuperfluities
Of baſers things, not being firſt improu'd.
I am his onely iſſue, and on me
I thinke he meanes to ſettle all his ſtate.
It's the onely way to giue me curſt and poore,
To build my neſt on ſuch extorted ſtore.
Thoſe fathers, that diſtreſſ'd mens ruines vſe,
" As ſcaffolds to build vp their racked wealth,
" Proue in the end, like citie-houſes, that
" On ſmall foundations carry ſpacious roofes:
" When the incenſed heauens in tempeſts frowne,
" Their owne top-heauy weight tumbles them downe.
" The firſt or ſecond generation ſpils
" By ryot, what by wrong the father fils.
In this Ile be a mirror to theſe times:
And by the hand of charitie returne
To euery man, what by his couetous rape
Their ſtates are rauiſh'd of: ſo worke my reſt.
Th'ill gotten gone, that which remaines is bleſt.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh Thirſty, honeſt Thirsty. Thy old maſter is but a dead man. I cannot piſſe man: my vrine's ſtop'd.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: You ſhould drinke, hard, maſter: all this comes with pinching your ſelfe of your liquour. This is the reaſon, that ſo few Dutchmen are troubled with the ſtone. Your miſerable Churle dribbles like the piſſing Conduit: but his iouiall ſonne with a ſtreame like Ware-water-ſpout. This is the cauſe, the Vſurer falling ſicke, ſo ſeldome riſes by the ſtaffe of Phyſicke: for he has no water for the Phyſician to caſt.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now the Gowt, Dropſie, Lethargie take poſſeſſion of their legs. I ha'loſt my wind, and my watch, and I feare, my wench too.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: You haue watch'd faire: ſure that Parſon was ſome Iriſhman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Some hangman vncaſe him. I ha'bene at the Parſons, and he's no ſuch manner of man.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What crew's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bleſſe your worſhip: I am your Worſhips ſonnes Tenant. I ha'brought a rogue to your worſhip, to be examin'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What fault hath has he committed? Clarke, to your office: take his examination. Now neigbour Sleepy, are you Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: A good harmeleſſe Conſtable, a theefe may take him napping.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your worſhip, the rude Raggamuſſin comes into my houſe, cals for drinke; and when the Tapſter came with a reckoning, he broke the pot about's head; becauſe he had not a cleane Apron on.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, becauſe he miſreckoned me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whoſe fault was it, to wipe out the ſcore?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Not mine. Indeede I anointed the ſcore with butter, and the Tapſters owne dog lick't it out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle, as ſure as my watch is loſt, this is maſter Valentine the Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh Coz, that it were true. Pray' Sir, let me mooue a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may command my anſwer Sir, y' are a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Were not you the man, that heald me o' the Gowt?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, I haue done ſo many cures, that I forget a number of my patients. Th'other day I cured a lunaticke
Cobler, pitifully run out at ſoule, when hee was giuen ore by the Phyſicians. I let him bloud, tooke three Hen-egges, ſuck'd 'hem out, into the ſhels I put his bloud, ſet them vnder a brood-Gooſe. When ſhe had hatcht the reſt, I gaue theſe three putrified egges to a Dogge: the Dogge grew madde, the Cobler ſober. And now my memorie runs backe, I call to mind one of Bedford, ſicke of the Gowt, whom I cured.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I am the man, my renowned Paracelſian: thou ſhalt haue the other 25. pound. Conſtable, I diſcharge you. Oſtice, I'le ſee you payd: ſet your recknoning on my ſcore: trouble me no further: leaue vs, leaue vs. Now my deepe diuer into the ſecrets of nature, I haue a cure for thee, more deſperate then the former.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What is't Sir, that my Art cannot extend to?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The ſtone, the ſtone: I am pittifully grip'd with the ſtone, I ha'loſt my piſſing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, the diſeaſe is ſomewhat dangerous.
Yet if that your expulſiue facultie
Retaine true force, I'le warrant to make you piſſe.
I muſt awhile withdraw to ſtudy Sir.—
Now am I puzzled: bloud, what medicine
Should I deuiſe to do't? It muſt be violent.
Giue him ſome Aqua-fortis; that would ſpeed him.
Let's ſee. Me thinks—a little Gun-powder
Should haue ſome ſtrange relation to this fit.
I haue ſeene Gun-powder oft driue out ſtones
From Forts and Caſtle-walls, huger then he
Has any in his reynes or bladder, ſure.
Faith,' cauſe I am a ſouldier, i'le make triall
Of that ſame blacke and vaporous Minerall.
I'le ſhoote into his belly: if the gunne hold,
I▪le giue him charge enough: ſome Aquavitae
Firſt brewd together would allay it well.
Ile ſweare to try it, if I doe not miſſe,
By a ſtrange tricke Ile make my Vſurer piſſe.
Sir, Ile goe in and prepare for aou.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p:
Doe ſo. Here, Thirſty, there be the Keys of the Buttry:
attend vpon him good Thirsty: let him lacke nothing, as thou lou'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: I loue you Maſter, but here's a good key I loue better. Sweete inſtrument of my ioy, let me kiſſe thee. Alas, that thou and I ſhould be ſuch ſtrangers. Wee ha' but one barrell: now if that ſhould bee in my maſters diſeaſe, troubled with the ſtrangullion, and could not runne—well, if it bee not emptie, Ile giu't a ſcowring.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now if this rare wonder of leaches can cure mee of this griping, that I may haue ſome fortie or threeſcore yeares more to gather in, by that time I ſhall gather enough to keepe me all the reſt of my life. When a man growes vp to to ſixe or ſeuen ſcore, it is high time to thinke of mortalitie, and to take ſome eaſe. Theſe three or foure nights I ha' bene haunted with Fairies: they dance about my bed-ſide, poppe in a peece of gold betweene the ſheetes, ſcatter here and there fragments of ſiluer, in euery corner. I keepe my chamber ſwept, cleane linnen, fire to warme them euery night. I was at firſt a fraide, they had beene ſpirits; now I ſee, they are good harmeleſſe Fairies.
