If I can pleaſe them, I ſhall grow rich, rich.
Sonne I haue ſtayd for you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You haue done your health the more wrong, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: How doſt like my morgage?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's a faire liuing, Sir; but I would not haue you meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why, my wiſe ſonne?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Oh Sir, good deeds are ſcant,
When we aduantage take of poore mens want.
sp.p: Bruſter's an honeſt man; lend him ſome money without ſuch ſharpe ſecuritie.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not a doyt. If he come to me, and conuey the morgage I haue it ready; els I haue no money.
Sonne come and ſup with me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I follow, Sir. Prepoſterous tranſuerſion of our ſelues!
Th'erection of our faces ſhould inſtruct
Our groueling thoughts t' aſcend. How do men thwart
The teaching hand of Nature, and our birth!
Our heads cut aire, and yet our hearts plow earth:
I looke for Sager here. He's come.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Heer's my owne caſe and counterfeit; by this dangerleſſe plummet, we may ſound the depth of his more cloſe and intricate ſtratagems.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So wiſer maſters lay ſome eaſie baites,
At once to tempt and trie their ſeruants truth.
The ſubiect for quack-ſaluing Empirickes
To exerciſe their inexperience on,
Should not be men, but malkins.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Do you thinke, that he would doe me violence aſleepe? would he not wake me to ſome conference?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No, hee's a moſt ranke Coward; and I know,
Dares not come neere thee, though thou wert aſleepe.
If he does ought, he'l do't by that long Engine.
Conceale your ſelfe awhile. How fares my name?
How does ſhe brooke my ſlow-pac'd comming to her?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Faith, in your conſtancie lightens all griefe.
She neuer heares you mention'd, but ſhe ſtartles:
As if your name like ſome celeſtiall fire
Quicken'd her ſlow-pac'd ſpirits with new life.
I neuer knew vertue and beauty meete
In a more happy mixture. I remoue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I loue her freely: ſhee's to me as th'ayre.
Her beauty is beſt and bleſt, whoſe ſoule is faire.
The Wolfe is come.
sp.stage: Enter Bromley with a fowling piece.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Good euening to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My wiſh requite you.
You walke to haue a ſhoot, Sir: I depart.
I would be loth to preiudice your ſport.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Saw you not Mr Sager, Sir, of late? This is his walke: I would faine ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why would you ſpeake with him?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Sir, for no harme.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I do not thinke you meane it; but you know, hee's valiant like a Lyon: if croſſe words ſhould ſtirre your blouds to quarrell—Sir, take heed. Hee'l be too hard for you, and your long weapon. This medow is his euening walke. Farewell to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Good night M. Beniamin; you need not doubt me.
If I could meet him at th' aduantage now,
He is the Fowle I'd ſhoot at. His life done,
The Farme is mine. Oh ye, whoſe hopes depend,
Like Imgring ſhadowes, on anothers end,
What need you waite with patience natures leaſure,
When ſuch an engine can ſoone work your pleaſure?
Tarry: yonder's a man—now by his habite
It ſhould be Sager. What? and faſt aſleepe?
Wiſh'd opportunity to my reuenge.
Ile kill him ere he wakes. Stay, grant he ſhould
In this vnbeaten medow lately act
Some horrid ſinne, pleaſe his adulterous luſt:
I ſhould then with his body ſtrike his ſoule,
And ſinke them both together. Reaſon no further
Thou chiding conſcience. See, the Fates haue plac't
Him ſit for vengeance: enemie, ſleepe thy laſt.
Hee's Planet-ſtrucke, falne downe: now to my Farme.
He that would riſe, muſt thanke his wit or arme.
Oh but my murder! piſh, who euer ſtood
In fortunes height, without ſome touch of blood?
sp.stage: Enter Beniamin and Sager at ſeuerall wayes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: This I diuin'd.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Happy preuention!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Goe, thou deſpairing wretch, and for thy will,
Ten thouſan ſwords ſhall thy vex'd conſcience kill.
'T was a vaine blow to vs, and no bloud ſpilt,
Not leſſe in thy intention is thy guilt.
This Clergy-habite which you haue aſſum'd,
Make good a while for your ſuppoſed death;
Allow his tyrannie free ſcope: liue cloſe:
Till time ſhall ripen thoſe euents, we ſtriue
To build on this vile ground. Hold, ther's my key:
Into my chamber; I ſup at my fathers.
What, come againe?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: I cannot be at reſt: I muſt needes ſee,
If this late murdered corps remoued be.
Some gold I haue put vp in this Portmantua:
If I ſhould be purſu'd, this may relieue me.
Ay me! the bodi's gone: ſure it's reueal'd:
Murder from heauens eye cannot be conceal'd.
What ſhall I doe? ſit downe: lye there, my gold.
sp.stage: Enter Nice, and Thirſty, on either ſide, crying So ho.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Holla, Couſin Beniamin. So ho ho.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Oh ho ho.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh me, the Countrie's vp, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This foole hath frayd him.
Oh guilt! how haſt thou made
Cowherd of man to fly at his owne ſhade!
Now Couſin Nice, what holla you for?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You had need of a bell to ring you in. Your father has ſtayd ſupper for you this houre.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come then, let's walke on—what's here a Portmantua?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, oh, do not touch it: it's venome.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why my wiſe Couſin? why are you ſo timorous?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh it lies there for a wager: there be theeues about it. Take heed Couſin; I found a Portmantua once, and loſt all the money in my purſe. Fly, fly—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Are you gone? Well, I ſee now, hee that will be wiſe by Calender, ſhall be a foole by deſtinie.
sp.l: Sure, this is Bromleys budget, and has gold
Put vp for his eſcape: 'tis ſo by th'weight.
It falls into my hands moſt luckily:
For I haue need of caſh in theſe occaſions.
Yet Ile repay't againe: my honeſtie
Shall be his friend, whoſe feare was friend to me.
Oh, in this glaſſe my repreſented ſoule
Stands manifeſt to my impartiall eye.
Ye heauens rayne ſhowers of mercy on my ſins:
Leſt where my pleaſure ends my wo begins.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: RVnne faſter, ye dull legges of motion,
That time may follow with a ſwifter paſe.
Let wanton Epicures wiſh you creeple-limbes,
Inſatiate with the ryot of their ioyes;
And chide the haſty forwardneſſe of day,
That will not dance attendance on their play.
My ſpirits wrought vpon with tedious woes,
Thinke that each houre lingring and lazy goes.
Impartiall fates, how you delude our thoughts!
Guiding euents to their determin'd ends,
Whether our ſtrength with or againſt contends.
Whether the paſſenger wake, or ſleepe his fill,
The waue and wind-mov'd veſſell goes on ſtill.
Patience then heart! they do not valour know,
That weary faint, but who can ſuffer woe.
Who's this?
sp.stage: Enter Rob. Vaſter with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By your leaue, Miſtris Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Right, th'haſt hit my name.
Yet cleare of ſinne, my ſorrow has no ſhame.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I haue letters from Mr. Ben. Gripe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: They're welcome. (poore boy how am I vndone!
Tis hard, a mother muſt not owne her ſonne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sure I ſhould know that face and language too.
A chill diſquiet troubles my ſoft peace,
And runs like a cold feuer through my bloud.
I'm very ſicke of ſomewhat. Oh 'tis then
Errour, the ſickneſſe in all minds of men.
But that I know her abſence giues her dead.
I' would ſweare it was my mother. 'las vaine thoughts,
How you would flatter me!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: —Your prouident friend, Beniamin Gripe.
Leaue out that Gripe: it's an vnproper name;
Cannot denominate thee for ſuch a creature.
A name can neuer conſtitute a nature.
If bleſſed mankinde haue a Phaenix left;
And vice of that good hath not time bereft;
In this degenerate worlds apoſtacie;
The plurall number's loſt: that one is hee,—Sonne

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Zlid ſhe calls me Sonne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That word's oreſlipt.
How eaſily loue is in her language trip't.
Sonne—of compelling nature not forbeares:
Paſſion muſt vent it ſelfe in ſpeech or teares.
Doſt thou not know me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes: this teſtifie.
I begge your bleſsing on my humbled knee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Riſe with heauen's benediction.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Liues my Father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Gueſſe by my greefe and ſilence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Vm'h my doubts
Wrappe me in further maze. My father dead?
My mother liuing in his enemies houſe?
Let's ſtudy. Oft I haue heard my father mone,
That this ſame womans luſt had him vndone.
This giues ſtrong faith. Why ſhould ſhee els liue here,
But to ſome ſuch vile end? By heauen tis cleare.
Oh that this ſappe, which my life feedes vpon,
Did not confeſſe a deriuation
From that corrupted trunke! Well, I will force
Nature runne backe with a prepoſterous courſe.
Ile faſhion a forgetfull lunacie,
That ere I was her ſoone. But on my ſoule,
Not touch her with leaſt hurt.—Woman come hither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Woman! Deare Robin, not thy mother? bleſſe mee.
Why doſt thou gripe me thus? Oh ſome blacke ſtorme
Is riſing on thy brow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Storme? No, tis thunder. Can you read this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, I can ſpell't too well. It ſpeakes my death, deare ſonne—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, come, forget
Theſe filiall rights, and Natures attributes.
Prepare your ſelfe to—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What? Oh deſperate child.
Oft haue thy bended knees with a iuſt dutie
Kiſs'd the cold earth, to begge my prayers to heauen,
For thy proſperity: oft deſir'd forgiueneſſe
Of thy wild infant-errors. Oft haue theſe
Borne thee with ſoft indulgence: but now, ſee,
A wofull mother bends her humble knee
To her incenſed ſonne; not to conſerue
This fleſh from death, but thy black ſoule from hell:
Th' vnſcaped dungeon, where all Parricides dwell.
Thinke: if thy ſpirits be not growne mad and wild,
Pitie a mother kneeling to her child.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'm deafer then an Vſurer to your mones.
I muſt, like Nero, ſee the place I bred in.
Be briefe in anſwere: did you neuer wrong my fathers nuptiall bed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Take heede.
Clogge not that breſt with more ſin, that muſt bleed.
Speake truth and ſaue your ſoule.
Lye you not here to ſatiate his luſt,
That robb'd my father? ſpeake, or y' are but duſt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No on my ſoule.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now on thy ſoule thou lyeſt.
Confeſſe, be plaine, or without pawſe thou dyeſt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Helpe, heauens or men.
sp.stage: Enter Benia. Valentine, Gripe, Nice, Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What prodigie's this?

sp.speaker: VVife.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, alas nothing: 'twas but my feare.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It is my ſeruant Sir; he meant no ill.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sonne, ſonne, howſoeuer he ſerues you, I'm ſure he does not ſerue God. Without queſtion, he would haue rauiſh'd her.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: He would haue refreſh'd her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Speake widow, is 't not true?—away with him.
Couſin Nice, make his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It's not amiſſe to let him feele ſome ſmart.
His life they cannot touch: what his offence
Deſerues in heauens, ſtrict iuſtice, mercy pardon.
Parents learne this in tendring Childrens ſtate:
Too much indulgence is not loue but hate.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sure his complexion doth not giue it: let me ſee your hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Will you feele it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: (Sonne offer violence to the mother?) ſtrange!
Till I can ſound this myſterie of ill,
Ile to the priſon and relieue him ſtill.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You will be gone Mr. Valentine; but I hope you wil viſit me ſhortly againe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Before you looke for me, Sir,—if all fall right,
I vowe to viſite you againe this night.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha widow! I am cleere of the ſtone now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The leſſe able to do a widow pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tut, wench, I meane the diſeaſe, the diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: (No Sir: you haue a worſe diſeaſe behind:)
The body hath no ſickneſſe like the mind.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Try me, ſweet. I'm like a leeke, though I haue
a gray head, I haue a greene—wut? wut be my medicine for the ſtone? when? when?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: When you haue married me I will be your wife.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Piſh: firſt make triall how thou likeſt me: there is no wit, to marry before experience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your houſe Sir, is too publike.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold, ther's the key of my cloſſet. Be thine owne pandar for conuayance. I muſt receiue a little money: profit is aboue pleaſure: about ten—

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Good lucke direct my hands vnto the morgage.
That found, if or my witte or ſtrength hold tacke,
I haue a medicine Sir, to coole your backe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Las poore wench: now ſhee's got into my Cloſſet, ſhe hugges her hopes, as a Polititian his ayery plotte, and cryes a prize, a prize. She ſhall be double cony-catch'd. Wel, it growes Fairy-time. Oh the fine dapper laddes, how they friske about my chamber: when at euery ſtep here droppes a grote, there a teſton. Many drops make a floud. Sure, I'm ſome wonderfull honeſt man, that they loue me thus. I muſt to bed. Tarry, how then ſhall I keepe touch with the widow? Tha't, Ile ſit downe in my chaire, and faine my ſelfe in a ſlumber. Oh 'twill be a golden waking dreame.
sp.stage: Enter Vaſter, Valentine, Curſew, like Fairies, dancing antickes: pinching Gripe, as they paſſe by him.
sp.p: Oh-oh-th' are angry. Would I were rid of 'hem. Oh—ſweet ſpirit—oh—doe not terrifie mee thus. What haue I done to prouoke you?

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Confeſſe thy ſinnes. Th' haſt ſome wench in a corner.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I haue, I haue—oh—but Ile not meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Whiles thy houſe was cleanly ſwept,
And thy conſcience chaſtly kept:
Neat linnen, fire and water ready;
And thy purpoſe good and ſteady:
Whiles thou neuer ſentſt the poore
Vnrewarded from thy doore.
Whiles thou wakendſt with the chimes,
Becauſe thou wentſt to bed betimes,
We brought thee wealth; but ▪twas in vaine:
For now we'll fetch it backe againe.
Come deliuer the keys of your trunkes.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh theenes, you'll robbe me, you'll vndoe me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, Gowtie bliſter, well bind thee, vndoe thee, who will—.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: Open thy iawes thou yawning ſepulcher:
Here is a morſel for an Vſurer.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: A peece of Cheeſe of the Low-country Dairies.
This is the vſuall diet of the Fairies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Now we will rip the lining of thy trunkes.
Better the Fairies haue it then thy punkes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lucke more, then we can carry, hath aſſign'd vs.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Each horſe his lode: we'll leaue the reſt behind vs. Thou greedy Panther.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sauage Wolfe.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Man-eater. Thou fettting Canker.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cōmons horſleech.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Cheater

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Whoſe belly has iuſt cauſe to ſue an action
Of treſpaſſe, gainſt thy couetous luſts exaction:
For detinie of many hundred meales,
Which it from others, and thy ſelfe too; ſteales.
The Gowt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Dropſie.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Collicke, Lunacie,
Like Sprites and Fairies haunt thy company.
And as thou gap'ſt now, let ſome Batte or Owle
Spet backewards i' thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: No more. If thou do not
Repent, reſtore, turne good, ſit till thou rot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What does Vſurie ſticke in thy teeth? ſpet out, Dog, ſpet out. Now thou gap'ſt for a morgage. Doſt?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Fare-ill. To thoſe that aske how came this euill, Giue anſwer thus: The Fairies robd the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh—Oh—Oh.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Ho maſter Gripe? what, your chamber doore ope thus carely? how now, bound? gagg'd? what rogues ha' bene here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Speake to mee vncle, ſpeake: the gagge's out.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Saue the gagge. I will hang the whole ſhire, but Ile find 'hem. Iugglers, Fairies, incarnall ſprites! My money, my heart, my guts, my ſoule—Let me curſe my ſelfe into the ground, and ſaue a Dirge. Run, cry, ride, charge the Conſtables with 'hem.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where be they, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gone to the Diuell. Runne to a Coniurer, caſt me a figure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, all the Coniurers are o' their owne trade. A miſchiefe on't, I thought there was ſome ſcuruy luck towards; the Crickets did ſo cry ith' Ouen yeſterday. And this verie houre, as we came in, there was an Owle whoo-whooping in the top of the chimney: and iuſt at the threſhold, maſter Bromley here ſtumbled Signes, ſignes.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Plucke downe the ſignes. Ile vndo all the Innes in the towne: they harbour the theeues.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: You ſaid they were Fairies.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now in ſinceritie, I heard a great ratling of chaines.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: (This makes mee wonder! ſuch a robbery, and I not heare it?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come bridle vp this furie. What will you ſay, if I can produce you the plotter, abbettor, or at leaſt acceſſary to this villanie? What if the pick-locke can open the cheſt of all this ſtratagem?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Las, poore widdow, ſhe was faſt, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, ſhe was looſe I warrant you: how could we haue got in, if ſhe had not open'd the dore? Your couſin Nice and I came from a hurly-burly ith' Iaile. Your ſonnes man has broke from his keeper. And as we were comming, wee met this woman verie ſupitiouſly ſtealing out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My heart miſgaue me thus: this diuels tongue
Would worke my miſdeem'd innocence ſome wrong.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words. Couſin, neighbor, take her to the next Iuſtice. I muſt not deale in my owne buſineſſe. Let her bee examin'd ſoundly, ſoundly: ſent to the Iayle, roundly, roundly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No more. Do not you know, I know you for a whore!
Away with her, I will not heare her ſpeake.
My gold, my ſiluer—Oh my heart will breake.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come, will you walke? Ile leade, widdow, come you next. Maſter Nice, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: As cloſe, as beggery followes drunkenneſſe.
Let me ſee your hand, widdow—Oh the caſe is cleare.
A yellow ſpot doth on your hand appeare.
Gather vp your heeles, widdow: Iuſtice Surly dwels hard by.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How now? my mother guarded? with two rogues?
Sword, thou didſt faine to kill her—but—Sirrah—you—deliuer me this woman, or Ile make thy yellow ſtarch'd face ſerue me for a cut-worke band.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh Sir, y' are well met; you broke from the Iayle laſt night. Apprehend him maſter Nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'am ſomewhat dainty and ſhy on him, Sir. He lookes vile ſharpe on't.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Let him looke as ſharpe, as an Apparitors nailes, we'll blunt him I warrant ye. Sirrah, I charge you ſtand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sirrah, you ſee I ſtand charg'd already. Will you haue me run?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh helpe, helpe—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I ha' not made my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: No matter for thy prayers; diſpatch it quickely then.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You'l giue me leaue, Sir, to make my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Then my will is—to runne away.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Thankes, ſonne; but now do you not, like the Lion,
Saue the diſtreſſed Lambe from the Wolfes pawes,
For ſacrifice to his owne bloudie lawes?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Deare mother, pardon; be ſecure—
sp.stage: Enter Bromley, Nice, Beniamin, Sager diſguiſed, Anne Vaſter.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: This way, this way: here—Oh haue we found you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How do theſe miſchiefes flutter in thicke heapes!
And cloud my vnderſtanding from the light,
I look'd the Sunne ſhould ſhine, find it darke night
I cannot ſtand t' examine circumſtances.
Now maſter Bromley, whither are you bound?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Your father gaue vs charge to haue the widdow
To maſter Iuſtice Surly's; he ſuſpects her
To haue ſome hand i'th robberie to night.
Sir it concernes you; he has loſt 300. pound.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Vmh. My father robd? the widdow charg'd with it?
Her ſonne vniayld himſelfe? theſe are harſh turnes.
Well, go you two before, prepare the Iuſtice.
You haue my word for their appearance. Go.
VViddow, and Robin, now here's none but friends:
You'l giue me leaue to wonder at theſe ends.
Of that anone.
Meane time I here preſent you with a gift,
Dearer to me, then is the Sunne to earth.
So; narrow vp your paſſions for a ſpace:
H'you the morgage-deeds? giue them my hands.
Yet the ſucceſſe on my innention ſtands.
Mother, and brother, (ſo I hope your titles)
My ſelfe, and friend here, whom you do not know,
VVill baile you both. That done, I haue an Inne,
Now voyd of Tennant; there dwell all together.
My friendſhip to the power ſhall pledge your faith.
Meaſure good deeds by what man would, not hath.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: VVhat Damn'd fortune's this, that I cannot ſmell out theſe theeues? I would ſweate them to the Gallous, as well as they ſwore me out of my money. An oath like a ſtrong charme, ſhould coniure their neckes into the circle of a rope.

Oh, here comes my fellow-Patient; wee both tooke Phyſicke together; purg'd, purg'd: but I haue a cordiall for him. Saue you, brother Gripe. Mr. Bromley, newes, good newes. It's reported, that Sager's dead.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Dead? Ile go take poſſeſſion preſently.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Do not with too ſtrict rigour exerciſe your power on his diſtreſſed family.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: My time is come, I will not loſe an houre.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's iuſt, that euery man ſhould take his owne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, you ſpeake law, not charitie. He that will
Be nothing more then iuſt, is vniuſt ſtill.
Wo to that quited ſoule, to whom from heauen
All iuſtice, and no mercie ſhall be giuen.
Your mercy to the widdow, to the Orphans.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: As much as a Puritan has vpon a good feaſt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Well—let me tell you this—Sager is dead.
So flies report, borne on preſumptions wings.
But how he dy'd, that aerie bird not ſings.
Kild—but by whom—waight deeply—I muſt hence.
The muttring's ſtrong—looke to your conſcience.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How's this? kild?—muttering? and conſcience? Looke, his ghaſtly melancholy points him out for the murderer. As ſure, as a hatte-brinkes puld downe declares a cuckold, this darkeneſſe diſcouers him.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Tell him, that knowes it not.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: My narrow heart cannot be capable
Of this huge bulke of ſorrow. It muſt out.
Now, to whoſe boſome better then my friends?
This hand kild Sager.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Nay, do your worſt.
Twas but chance medley, accidentall ſlaughter.
Intending with my Peece to ſtrike a fowle,
Againſt my will the cocke went downe, and he
Stood in deaths way. It was his deſtinie.
But Griffin, harke you—let not your tongue ſtirre.
Do not I know you for a forgerer?
And more—you wot—let not your tongue be looſe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thus are two Foxes catch'd in one poore nooſe.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.l: Our guilt ſhall bind our ſecrecie; who liues
An vnſuſpected villaine, winks at others
Vnlawfull deeds, to teach their eye-lids how
To winke at his—Shall we go to our new Hoſtice?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where? who?

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: For your where, at the Maiden-head, a good likely place. For your who: the wid dow that old Gripe ſuſpects for the robbery; but young Gripe hath tenanted to his Inne. Maſſe, ſhe preuents vs. Widdow, we were comming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray' Gentlemen walke in; you ſhall haue attendance.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Your company, ſweete widdow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ile not be long from you, Sir.
Oh, ſome retiring from this houſe of ſinne.
Fate! I was neuer bred to keepe an Inne.
sp.stage: Enter Curfew, Valentine as themſelues, Vaster diſguis'd.
sp.l: More cuſtomers? that which all Innes would ſee;
Great ſtore of gueſts: this is a plague to me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Yonder's mine Hoſtice. Now the water's vp, that we cannot get ouer to the Abbey, it is our ſecureſt courſe to commit the money to her cuſtodie. If any ſearch ſhould be made, and theſe tokens found about vs, we are all dead men: there's not ſo much mercie in Gripe, as in the Plague.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Widdow, we haue ſome money to pay to a Londoner in Bedford here; and he's not yet come to receiue it. Will you locke it vp ſafe for vs?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But heare you? Deliuer it not to any one of vs. Except all three demand it to gether, keepe it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Helpe her to beare it in, and ſee't layd vp.
Zlid, my wife takes degrees; ſhe riſes fairely.
I ſold her hither whore ſome trickes to do.
Now ſhe's turn'd whore, and Bawd, and Hoſtice too.
Stand cloſe deare wits, and ſhadow me diſguiſe.
She caſt me downe, and by her fall Ile riſe.
Husbands that loue your honour as your life;
Learne now to be reueng'd, on a falſe wife.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Your friends expect you Sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sweet, I would go.
But here's a charming beauty, that ſayes no.
Will you walke off a little—to the meddow?
I haue a tiny buſineſſe with you, widdow?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What is your will, Sir? I'm in haſte: be ſhort.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: The thing thou wotſt on, halfe a minutes ſport.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Forbeare, libidinous Groome.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Groome? I'm a man.
And can do, Hoſtice, what another can.
Come, ſhall I ſpeake in gold, and action?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Be damn'd, inchanter, with thy golden ſpelss.
Thou thinkſt, gold can buy luſt, when nothing els.
Yet I do loue thy ſoule. Think, ethinke, how deare,
A moments ioy is bought with endleſſe feare.
How ill the fleſh ſteales his vniuſt delight,
When the ſoule ſuffers an eternall night.
Flatter thy glowing hopes with heate no more.
Be not deceiu'd; thy Hoſtice is no whore.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: So: ſpoke my out-ſide braue; did my rich huske
Allow me impudent; and my vndown'd chinne
Promiſe my bloud vnſuck'd out by this ſinne,
You would runne madde on me.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Sooth, thou much erreſt.
I neuer ſaw that perſon (except one,
Who iuſtly claim'd my loue, now dead and gone)
In whoſe embracements I would ſooner locke the treaſures of my heart.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: Now, now, ſhe's comming.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: If you had mou'd my eares with a chaſt ſuite, I ſhould haue liſtn'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋast.
sp.p: Braue! ſhe's mine already.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I cannot loue theenow.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p:
No, I cannot
conceiue a good thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Heigh? handy, dandy, faſt and looſe, braue diuell.
Ile coniure you for this. Come, will you loue me?
Or no matter for your loue, will you lie with me?
Doe, or lie alone i'th meddow here. I ſhall leaue your tempting eyes for the Crowes to picke out.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Defend me goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Whiſtle not ſo lowd, leſt I cut your pipe, Come on.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Honour or life, how ſhall I ſaue you both?
Sir, I ſhall ſpoyle you. I ha'bene long a ſinner.
A common ſinner, Sir, and am not ſound.
You cannot ſcape infection, if you touch me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Humh! the poxe, ſay you? well, you'l not reueale me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You need not, Sir, diſtruſt my ſilence. Wrongs
That ſcape heauens hand, need not feare mortall tongs.
This world's turn'd Bedlam, rauing, deſperate-badde.
It ſtagger'd drunke before, now it runs mad.
More cuſtomers?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But, Sir, reſpect your life, your conſcience.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou ſaiſt well, for my life. But for my conſcience▪ Tis like a Surgions, that takes money for letting out blood. Thinke o' my morgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Vpon my life, he'll kill her. O preſumption,
How doſt thou dare heauens iuſtice? I muſt ſtudy
To interpoſe prevention. Sir, I'm your ſonne:
This breſt you gaue me, and Ile ſtill conſerue it,
A faithfull cloſet to locke vp your ſecrets.
How will you ſtrike? Piſtoll her?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No: that ſpeakes
Like an obſtreperous Aduocate, too loud,
In th'cares of iuſtice. Murder, like your Ieſuite,
Should whiſper death in ſilence—ſleeping ſilence.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I apprehend it, poyſon. Sir, Ile buy you
A ſpeedy potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Not too deare, good ſonne.
I would not ha't too deare: my mony's gone.
Two peny-woorth of Rats-bane, w' haue experience,
W'll do't; do't throughly.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile prouide it, Sir.
Ile be your Apothecarie; but by no meanes
Miniſter it my ſelfe. You muſt do that, Sir:
I cannot doe you better ſeruice. Rare!
Then bring my father to the Galhouſe.
Be petulant, and let your wanton mirth,
Giue you forgetfull of all wrong.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come widow, I forgiue thee now: I hope thou't forgiue me too. I'm come to drinke downe all malice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray' Sir, lead the way. Ile follow.
Looke vp, deare friend: what thus deiects you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wonders, miracles—I muſt needs poyſon thee.
Be not diſmay'd, my poyſon ſhall not hurt thee:
Ile tell thee all▪

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.p: Hoſtice, Pray 'helpe me to the money quickly. I muſt pay't inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: So, if my new-borne plots hold conſtant life▪
Ile cheate my theeues, but aboue all, my wife.
Thanke you, good Widow. Youth, tel the
Gentlemen I'm gone to tender the money. Bid
sp.p: 'hem be merry and continue their healths. Ile take my round, when I come againe. Farewell Oſtice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Y'are welcome Sir,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gone, ſayſt thou? and with the mony? fire and gunpowder! how are we blowne vp?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Prettie handſome!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oſtice—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Good leach, ſtand further off: your breath's too violent▪

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Did we not charge you not to deliuer the money, but to vs all three together?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Maſſe, tis true. How forgetfully are we cheated?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a coozening woman.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You doe lye!

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Keepe the peace. Oſtice, you'l make it good to vs, three hundred pound, a pretty competent ſumme.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Furies and Fiends! wits, you do fairly ſtriue.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I thought this faiery mony would nere thriue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue heard all this roguerie.
Cheare, Widow: let not ſorrow make thee ſicke.
Perhaps, Ile catch the knaues at their owne tricke.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p:
So ho-my maſter's turn'd Reueller. I neuer loſt my name
ſince I came into his ſtaruice, till now. Vck! a miracle, I am not Thirſty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now my wiſe kindred, why looke you ſo pale?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, Ile put off my wedding. I will not for all Bedford marry to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No? why?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, my Vncle reaching for a Cup, ouerthrew the ſalt towards me—towards me. O tis ominous.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The falling of a ſalt keep thee from mariage! well, I haue a ſtrange medicine, of quick cure to this conceited ſickneſſe. Robin, fetch me ſome wine. Coz, how doſt feele thy ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Hee ſhakes as if he had the gurning agew.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Perplexed Couſin, perplexed. I had rather a good Lordſhip had falne toward me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut man, ſalt ſeaſons all things; fiſh or fleſh.
And troth, thou need'ſt it: for thy witte's but freſh.
Here bloud, I drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Now could I dance like a Dutch Froe: my heeles are as light as my head.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh I recant. Couſin, I will marry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What meant you Sir, to ſpill the wine vpon him?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: 'Twas a miſchance Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No: it was good hap.
Tis a good ſigne, t' haue wine ſpilt in ones lappe:
This makes amends for the ſalt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I thought this docke would fetch your nettle out.
I ſee. ſmall wind turnes a fooles mill about. Let's goe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yonder comes my Phyſician and his potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I haue here two papers: one of ſugar, and that's for my ſelfe: another of poyſon, and that's for my Oſtice. Let me be right-right. I ſhould make faire worke, if I were miſtaken now. Ha widow! th' art a Churle-a very churle, that wouldſt not keepe companie with thy gueſts. I ha' brought thee a cup of wine here: health and bloud to thee, ſweete Widow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A miracle: An Vſurer drunke at's owne coſt.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: There's a whole cup for thee: pledge mee chucke. Nay tarry, tarry: thou muſt haue ſugar to 't; women loue ſweet things, I know. So, off with't bottome and all: the deeper the ſweeter. Ha Oſtice, my ſonne ſhall giue thee a leaſe of thine Inne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would hee could grant me a leaſe of my life: for I grow ſick ſir. Robin, looke in.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (Excellent ratteſ-bane) it workes already. Widow, doſt remember ſince thou waſt in my ſtudie? and y faith what foundſt there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nothing, but what I left behinde me, Sir. I'm very ſicke.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (Ile nere truſt poyſon els.) This cottons wel yet. No ſooner dead, but my ſonne ſhall ceaze on all the goods. Search the coffers for my morgage. If it be loſt, yet now ſhee I keepe counſell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This wine hath made me thirſty: I'm not well.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hye thee to bedde and ſweat. A little poſſet with two-penny worth of horſe-ſpice. O tis excellent to put one into a ſweat. Farewell widow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So I'm recouerd now: thy abſence cures me.
O earth! thou center of the world and ſinne;
Tſty Paradiſe is loſt t'th'art only now
A larger ſtable, where all vices dwell.
Did not the Sunne ſhine, I ſhould thinke thee hell.
sp.p: Lucky! here comes the cheater. Sir, the money is askt for by the Gentlemen, your friends: They threaten to arreſt me, but I hope ſir, you'l be my quittance.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Yes: on this condition.
Let me enioy thy loue on this ſoft ground:
Ile pay it backe, were it three hundred pound.
Stirre not: this chargeth you: are you not content?
Come, with a ſilent kiſſe ſeale your conſent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, you know my diſeaſe. I'm dangerous.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p:
The poxe? O I haue knowne London too long to bee
afraid of the poxe. Come, will you vnlocke? I ha' the golden key. If not, Ile to Virginia, like ſome cheating Bankrout, and leaue my Creditour ith' ſuddes. You know the Iayle. Ha you neuer bin hir'd to yawle for the whole priſon? and whule to the paſſengers?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sorcerer, thy circle cannot hold me.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.p: No, I would haue yours holde mee. Come, will you fadge?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not, if thou killſt me: not if thy murderous hand
Could put me to a death▪ (like Ieſuites poiſon)
Ten yeeres a dying.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No? you will repent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So wilt thou neuer: take my carcaſe, ſlaue:
Whiles there's a ſoule within; no luſtfull hand
Did or ſhall euer touch it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Politick whore!
What do you ken me now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My husband? ô,
Into your armes I flie.

sp.speaker: Ʋaſt.
sp.l: Infection, no.
Y are dangerous by your owne confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas! I forg'd that anſwere, to auoid
Sinfull embracings. Brothels ſicke indeed
Of that contagion, ſooth and ſmother't vp,
To tempt diſtruſtfull commers on, at once
To their owne profit, and the others ruine.
They ſpeake falſe, to do falſe the ſafer. I
To ſaue my conſcience did my fleſh bely.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: You cannot tempt me Siren; I am reſolute.
Thou art a cunning Bitch, and I am proud
Of ſuch expected meanes to my reuenge.
Harke, how Ile quittance thy abhorred luſts.
Firſt, thou ſhalt be arreſted for the money,
Whereof I cheated thee: ſo be reſtrain'd
From thy old ſtraggling, mew'd vp like a haggard;
Till the Aſsiſe comes, then thou ſhalt be hang'd.
I heare thou ſtandſt bound ouer for ſuſpicion
Of robbing Gripe. I did the villanie.
Ile ha't prou'd thine: ſo thou ſhalt hang for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Deare husband, do ſo.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Husband me no more:
That name was cancell'd when you firſt playd whore.
Now garden-pot, you water your ſad feares,
But I am no loue-foole, wonne with womans teares.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O proſecute your wil. Thus on my knees,
And with a heart more humbled, I intreat,
And I muſt haue it granted ere I riſe;
Be pleas'd to make this life a ſacrifice,
To expiate your wrath. I freely yeeld it,
For your redemption. For your hate I dye;
That might not liue in your loues companie.
If I confeſſe not guilty, to ſaue you,
Imagine then all your ſuſpicions true.
But when for your debts I haue payd this life,
Beleeue but then, you had a faithfull wife.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: O, thou wouldſt melt a rocke. My heart's too dead,
To ſprout at this wet Aprill. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Peace and content attend you: and let ſtill
Mercie forgiue, and rectifie your ill.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What? not dead yet? but weeping? come, come dry
Vp all thy teares: goe hye thee in, and dye.
Much villanie is now together pack't.
The Scene growes full. Your patience this laſt act.

div.head: Act. Quint.
div.stage: Enter old Brace, the true Abbot. Abbot.
div.l: TO man, how ſweet is breath! yet ſweeteſt of all,
That breath, which from his natiue ayre doth fall.
How many weary paſes haue I meaſur'd!
How many knowne and vnknowne dangers paſt,
Since I commenc'd my tedious Pilgrimage,
The laſt great worke of my death-yeelding age!
Yet am I bleſt, that my returning bones
Shall be rak't vp in Englands peacefull earth.
Oh happy Engliſhmen, if your ſore eyes
Did not looke ſquint on your felicities!
How other Countries enuy, what you loth,
And ſurfet on: and would make that their pride,
Which is by your contempt ſtill vilefied!
This ſickneſſe fulneſſe breedes in moſt mens blood;
None leſſe, then the poſſeſſors, know what's good.
Now to my deputy: here his glories end.
But ſtay: he comes to meet me. Ile attend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Confound this damn'd foxe: he has cheated mee of the beſt prey, I euer ſhark'd for. Would I could light on him; I haue a Conſtable here ſhould make him ſtand.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: What's this? ſharking, foxing, and a piſtoll?
Th'embleme of theefe, cheater, murderer?
Sure, this vile Elderne was not of my planting.
I know him: Tis his brother, to whoſe truſt I did infeoffe my place.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: I was directed this way to the Abbot.
My lord—the Iudge detain'd by ſickneſſe from to morrow's Seſſion, deſires your lordſhips ayde to the ſupply of his owne place. Th' aſsiſtant Iuſtices reſt their determining ſentence on your lippes.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile giue my old attendance.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Your lordſhips leaue.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I leaue your lordſhip too.
I muſt about this miſchiefe to preuent:
Ile force you both your offices repent.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo. My cuſtomers drop in roundly. Welcome, Mr. Gripe, and the reſt of my good friends, welcome! I am very glad to ſee you here. My houſe was not grac'd with an Vſurer, and vnder-Sheriffe, many a day before; though I ha' been peſter'd with abundance of honeſter fellowes. Speake, ſhal' • be merry? what will you haue to dinner?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A rope. What doſt thou tell me of dinner?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: No Sir, that ſhall be kept for your ſupper.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Giue me ſo me Sacke and Aqua vitae. I wil be drunk preſently.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's cleere. I haue twenty caſes for't.
The concealing of murder is but man-ſlaughter. I muſt ha' my booke.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Giue 's ſome Sacke, I ſay: mun tut, &c.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: My Vncle committed? Iuſtice it ſelfe ſent to the Iayle?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Couſin, ſweet Couſin, runne, ſcudde, fly—to Sir Bare Notwithſtanding: he lyes but three miles off; he's in my debt: bid him releaſe me, and Ile releaſe him.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Stay Sir. He's in my debt too: I ha' ſolicited for Sir Bare theſe ſeuen yeeres, and haue nothing but bare thankes.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Nay then, take me with you. Thus—
sp.stage: Enter Beniamin, Robin, Thirſty; Thirſty climbing vp into a tree. Rob. into a buſh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ha you your leſſon perfect?

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Yes, yes: as a Mid-wife her errand to a Citizens wife. There's not an Owle in an Iuy-buſh, nor a Parrat at a Drugſters dore, has whoo whoop, or walke Knaue, more perfit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Robin, do't cunningly. My Dad ſhall be
Only to me beholding for his life.
By that aduantage I recall his loue.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Couſin, fly euery ſtep. Remember, like a Iury-man, you goe vpon life and death.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Happineſſe grant, that no Hare croſſe him ith' way: his ſuperſtitious legges will retire, though wee hang for't. Come, ſhall we keep the rule of the place, and drinke drunke now?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now kindred, whither trot you ſo faſt?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh Couſin, about a deede of charitie; to ſaue your father, and two or three knaues more from hanging. I am going to Sir Bare Notwithſtanding; to ſaue them out of priſon: they haue ſau'd him often.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir Bare Notwithſtanding, he's a great man, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hee had three Lordſhips fell to him at a clappe; the worſt worth 400. a yeere.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet hee's bare notwithſtanding.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hee has ſold his Caroch with foure Flanders mares, becauſe he would retire himſelfe and liue ith' Country.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet he's Bare Notwithſtanding. But to himſelfe Couſin, farewell.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: To him, quoth he? I will to him, were the diuell in my way.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Porke, porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: The diuell porke you. What diſmall bird crokes diſaſter to my iourney!

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, if the deſtinies haue ſet the Rauen againſt mee, Ile rerurne ſure—yet let me ſee. So my Vncle may bee hang'd, Ile on, come what will.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: O this blacke bird tolles like a paſsing-bell,
My owne ſad miſchiefe and my Vncles knell.
Yet why am I ſo timorous; when charitie
Bids me go on, ſhall a Rauen hinder me?
Ile keep alooſe and paſſe—oh a ſpirit, a ſpirit.
The Widdowes Ghoſt. Bromley, Lawyer, Vncle, hang.
Take all your fortunes, I'le no further gang.
It's an vnhallow'd place, a diſmall day.
Betide what will, Il'e backe againe ſome way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Come downe, Rauen.

sp.speaker: Thirſt.
sp.p: Come out, Spirit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Blind, credulous foole! He that ſhall truſt at need
Such nice and tottring cockſcombes, ſhall thus ſpeed.
Should his ſicke father ſend him for ſome drugges,
Hee would turne backe at ſuch imagin'd bugges.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, mother, friend, and wife; take theſe back places,
Where you may heare vnſeene: that when time ſerues,
I may produce you. Works and houres are ſpent
Then well, when we doe good, or ill preuent.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: I cannot iudge, what is this dayes ſucceſſe.
All-ruling powers the doubtfull ſequele bleſſe.
sp.stage: Enter Curfew with other aſſiſtants, Ʋaster in a Prieſts habit, Ʋalentine like a Phyſician, the Iaylor with Gripe, Bromley, Griffin, &c.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: My Lord, whoſe place I perſonate, being ſicke,
Hath thus deſign'd mee, both to heare and cenſure
The criminall cauſes, which offend the peace
Of our dread Soueraigne, and his ſubiects weale.
Whiles we launce Vlcers, we the body heale.
The charge I giue in ſhort, you of the Iury,
Looke to your Oath and conſcience: let not fauour
Shut vp your eyes, nor malice open them
Too wide. You vnderſtand, our lawes are good.
Tis pitie that they ſhould be writ in blood.
But ſince conniuence at vnlawfull deeds
Giues but encouragement, and wee cannot ſtrike
With ſword of Iuſtice the deſeruing faults,
Except you giue the perſons to our hands:
All on your vigilant information ſtands.
Proceede to the Inditements.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: We are all caſt away. Sir Bare is not come.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pull downe that counterfeit, proud, arrogant, puffe:
Could your intruſion not content it ſelfe
T'vſurpe my office, but you muſt abuſe
The Kings deputed Iudge?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Downe with him, downe with him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Iaylor, receiue him to your cuſtodie,
Till our iuſt cenſure giue him puniſhment.
Foxe, I ſhall hunt you out.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Do't with a poxe.
The gooſe ſometimes muſt ſit and iudge the Fox.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Proceed; the day haſtens.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Marian Sorrow widow, yeeld thy body, and ſaue thy baile.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir, ſhee is dead: her felonie is anſwer'd Before a higher Court.

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p: That is the woman that Gripe is ſuſpected to haue poyſon'd. Godfrey Gripe ſtand to the Barre. You are indited for the murther of Marian Sorrow widdow: guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not guilty, my Lord: let all the world teſtifie of my honeſt carriage. I haue liued all my dayes in good name and fame.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Stand not vpon your credit and good deeds.
Your harueſt would be ſmall, if like your ſeeds.
If all that know thee ſtood about this place,
And had free liberty to ſpeake their thoughts,
Round ecchoing curſes would amaze thy ſoule,
And with hells damned crue thy name enroule.
But when the Widdow, Orphane call for plagues
On thy blacke life, thou hy'ſt vnto thy bagges;
There doſt applaud and hugge thy wretched ſelfe:
As ſolace 'gainſt all woes lay in thy pelfe.
Thou haſt no god but gold: that Deitie
Thou ſhouldſt adore, and would ſtill ſuccour thee,
Is quite reiected. And that Idol, money,
Which beares away thy confidence and heart,
When thou art plagued, aggrauates thy ſmart.
Thou art the Deuils Executioner.
His rankeſt plague on earth's an Vſurer.
Spirits in hell whip ſoules: extorting ſlaues
Torment poore bodies ſo before their graues.
Thou art a gulfe, poore mens eſtates to drinke.
A quagmire; none paſſe ore thee, but they ſinke.
Vnleſſe Strepſiades-like, men could deuiſe
To plucke the Moone by Sorcerie from the skies;
Thy moneth and gaine will come. Like ſome at ſea,
(Yet dangerleſſe of ſhipwracke more then they)
Thou ſlumbreſt in a baſe lethargicke ſwoone.
Let others toyle, thy iournye's done as ſoone.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will not this moue him?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Nature in all inferiour things hath ſet
A pitch or terme, when they no more ſhall get
Increaſe and off-ſpring. Vnrepayred houſes
Fall to decay: old Cattell ceaſe to breed.
And ſappeleſſe trees deny more fruite or ſeed.
The earth would hart-leſſe and infertile be,
If it ſhould neuer haue a Iubile.
Only the Vſurers money genders ſtill:
The longer, luſtier: Age this doth not kill.
He liues to ſee his moneys moneys money,
Euen to a hundred generations reach.
He, whiles his intereſt money in do's troule,
Cares not to loſe the principall, his Soule.
He like a cleanly Alchymiſt can ſoke
And draw much ſiluer, yet waſte none in ſmoke.
Thou lendſt, like water powr'd on ſea-cole fire,
Or on a lode of Lime a ſhowre of rayne.
sp.p: It ſeemes to coole heate, but doth more enflame.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: His conſcience has deafe eares.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: When all is done,
And thou haſt ſwel'd thy heapes; to ſay no more,
Thy coffer's onely rich, and thou art poore.
This common plague is on all Vſurers ſhowne:
Th'haue much, yet are not maſters of their owne.
One day thy ſtintleſſe mind ſhall haue enough;
When the diuided peeces of thy ſelfe
Shall in their ſeuerall doomed manſions dwell:
Enough of mould in graue, of fire in hell.
But I ſpend breath in vaine; come, let's proceed.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: No further. You haue made my conſcience bleed.
I heere confeſſe my ſelfe guilty of all,
Euen of this murder too.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Let mercie fall on thy diſtreſſed ſoule. Now to the reſt.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Nicholas Bromley, you are indited for the murther of William Sager, &c. Guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Not guilty? Who teſtifies againſt me!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: In caſe of Murder ſhould we neuer iudge
By circumſtanciall likelihoods and preſumptions,
No life could be ſecure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puffe! ſhift for your ſelues; Sir Bare Notwithſtanding dares not be ſeene.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: O, I am loſt.
My Lord, I'm guilty: ſo is Griffin too:
He did conceale the fact, that I did doe,
We ſhar'd the Lands together.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.l: Powerfull truth!
Murder will out, though by the Actors mouth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: O Beniamin, I haue vndone
My life, my ſtate, my credite, and my Sonne.
But I'm reſolu'd to dye, ſo Monarchs muſt:
Rich men as well as poore, muſt turne to duſt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Me thinkes I could preuent all this.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Alas, thou lov'ſt me; but tis not poſsible.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, I haue here a booke already drawne,
Seale to it freely, and Ile ſaue your life.
You ſhall confirme me your vndoubted heire,
And then ſurrender Vaſters morgag'd lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My Lord and all this bench be witneſſe to it.
Then thus I quit you, widdow, appeare in Court.
In earneſt, ſee, ſhe liues, that dy'd in ſport.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, thanke your Drugſter, elſe I had dy'd by you.
And you for me receiu'd a murderers due.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: So, I am couſen'd finely, finely—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord, I challenge this widdow for cheating me of 300. pounds. This is one of her old trickes.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord, my ſelfe and two intruſted friends
Came hither to pay money on a bond,
Whiles the receiuer did deferre his comming;
We gaue this coozening woman, being Hoſtice,
The whole ſumme to lay vp: and ſtraightly charg'd her,
Not to deliuer't, but to vs all together.
She ſayes one of vs three demanded it
Of her in haſte, and ranne away: and thus
We loſt our money, and the bond lies forfeit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your Lordſhips leaue. Tis true, ſhe not denies,
But they ſo charg'd her, and ſhe was ſo coozend.
Therefore ſhe yeelds to paiment. Let 'hem come
All three together, they ſhall haue the money.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Vpon my faith, a prettie quillet.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Wittie and iuſt. How ſay you? heere produce
The other two, your ſatisfaction's ready.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The widdow's cleard: but maſter Valentine—
Nay, man, come neerer, you'd haue preſent pay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir, let it euen goe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So muſt not you.
You gaue 300. pound to her: tis true.
Which like a ſubtle Quackſaluer, you robd
My father of; Sprites, Fairies—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am cob'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: It's true, my lord: this is one of the Fairies. Iuſtice, Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, if there be no remedie, I hope,
I ſhall not dance alone vpon the rope.
My lord, here's the other Fairie.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: O Sir, haue I found you?
Pull off that borrowd habite from his backe.
O that ſuch foule deeds ſhould be hid in blacke.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: My Lord, this Widow's acceſſary too:
She plotted, ſhe receiu'd. Iuſtice, iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: But late thy ſong was mercy, now all iuſtice?
Here's all the goodnes of an Vſurer.
She ſau'd his life, he would now hang her.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: She has robb'd me, vndone me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is moſt true, my lord, ſhe plotted all.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: (Your villanie, Oſtice, we ſhall now retort.
You cheated vs, and we will hang you for't.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How doe theſe miſchiefes grow, like Hidra's heads, faſter by cutting off!

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Prodigious villaines! will they thus caſt away an innocent woman?
Yet I moſt vile of all, that thus ſtand by,
And for my fault behold my poore wife dye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My lord, vpon my ſoule this woman's cleare:
And only malice thus accuſeth her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake, woman, art thou guilty?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My lord, I begge a word with my Confeſſor,
Then I ſhall anſwere. Sir, a word in priuate.
Now Vaſter, ope thy vnbeleeuing eyes:
Lo, thy deuoted wife for thy ſinne dyes.
Yeeld but this kindneſſe to my lateſt breath,
Thou hate'ſt me liuing, loue me yet in death.
Farewell—My lord, I will not ſay, I'm guilty;
Do as your euidence and wiſedome leades you.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: This knot is hard to vndo.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: My lord, Ile help you.
Loe, I am that third Fairy, that pronounce
This woman cleare, and thoſe two periur'd knaues.
We three are guilty: let your ſentence come.
I haue deſeru'd, will not deſpaire my doome.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My lord, he ſayes not true: hee's innocent: I guilty.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake on your ſoules, which of theſe tongues ſpeak truth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Curf. My lord, the woman's cleare.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pernicious Villaines, hopeleſſe to be good:
That thus haue ſtroue to ſpill the guiltleſſe bloud.
Widow, y' are quitted. Sir, waite you your doome.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: With patience. Beniamin Gripe, I here accuſe you for murdering Richard Vaſter.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: My lord, I found that Vaſter dying, bury'd him,
Saw him receiuing death by this mans ſword.
Theft's a great ſin, but murder moſt abhorr'd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake; is this poſsible?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We met in ſingle combate in the field:
It ſeemes his life vnto my ſword did yeeld.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ay me, my father ſlaine?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And by his friend?
Fate, whither will thy proiects tend!

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My husbands hand my fathers life vndoes:
For this fact he muſt dye: thus both I loſe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgiue me all, by me you all haue loſt,
The wife a Husband, children a deare Parent:
Thus I returne you all ſome recompence.
Nan thou ſhalt loſe a husband.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Heauens defend.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Mother, you loſe a ſon, brother a friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Can nature ſo degenerate, that a man ſhould liue, ſtand by, and ſee another ſuffer for murdering him?

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Once againe off diſguiſe.
My lord, thus I preuent this fear'd diſaſter
My ſecond caſe pull'd off, I am plaine Vaſter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My deare husband.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Moſt, moſt deare friend.
My loue to you doth beyond bounds extend.
My Lord, firſt to this honourable Bench,
I'here preſent the Kings moſt gtacious pardon
For vs three here: heauen no leſſe pardon vs.
Now to my wife: ſee wench, I am new borne;
Renc'd from the plague of a ſuſpected horne.
Blacke Iaundeys of the minde, thou fained ſpirit,
That haunts mens quiet thoughts with troubling ſhades.
Pernicious Ielouſie, that like needleſſe Phyſicke
Diuerteſt health to voluntary ſickneſſe,
I bruſh thee off like duſt. See, I am now
New marry'd to my loue and to my life.
Neuer could man boaſt a more conſtant wife.
Deare Beniamin, now Sonne, what I haue left
Of all my ſhipwrack'd fortbnes, ſhall be thine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Reſume your former ſtate, my father yeelds it.

sp.speaker: Vaſt.
sp.l: Thankes to your honeſtie, not his; yet thus,
Some meanes of ſatisfaction I haue found;
Ile pay him backe his loſt three hundred pound:
The fairie money, which was iuſt the price
Of my redeemed lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now maſter Bromley,
That vniuerſall mercie to our guilt,
May be affoorded, and no blood be ſpilt:
Surrender vp your leaſe for the three liues
To Sagers wife and children, and Ile quit you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I do moſt freely yeeld it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Sager liues,
And hartie thankes for your forc'd kindneſſe giues.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Happy deluſions! in ſuch waies of ill,
I wiſh men may be thus miſtaken ſtill.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Rauens, and Sprites, and Fairies, and Hares and diuels-Thus haue I loſt my wench, loſt my money, loſt my watch, loſt my wits. I doe here renounce the faith of all Almanackes, Phyſiogmoners, Palmiſts, Fortune-tellers. Erra Pater was an Aſſe, and ſo are Prognoſticators, his children, from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I haue drunke powerfull phyſicke, and the Dropſie
Of my (till now) nere quenched auarice,
Dries vp like dew at the aſcending Sunne.
Vaſter, take back your lands; and for the money,
Giue it my ſonne in portion with your daughter.
Hencefoorth Ile ſtudy to requite the wrongs,
Which I haue done poore men by vſurie,
And vomit vp th'extortions, that doe lie
As vndigeſted crudities on my conſcience.
My future life ſhall bee in mercie ſpent.
I'm Gripe no more; that name I doe repent.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: All Chronicles be fill'd with this; and let it
Beas a wonder to all eares imparted.
England had once an Vſurer conuerted.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: THe Seſſion now diſſolues: each Iuſtice riſes:
No hurt is done; this is the milde Aſſiſes.
We haue ſcap'd faire thus farre: yet there remaines
A ſtronger iudgement to paſſe on our paines.
Too much to hope or doubt we muſt not dare.
We humbly then ſtand at your cenſures barre.
If the worſt comes that may be, yet I looke
For this grace, to be ſaued by my booke.
But if with your applauſe our merit ſtands:
Faith then be friends with vs, and giue's your hands.
